      1. Calculating the CDF of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Calculating the time derivative ∂tQρtsubscript𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡\partial_{t}Q_{\rho_{t}}∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.
    5. A.5 Additional Details on the Experiments
      1. Implementation and evaluation details.
      2. Choice of latent distribution.

Neural Sampling from Boltzmann Densities:
Fisher-Rao Curves in the Wasserstein Geometry

Jannis Chemseddine, Christian Wald, Richard Duong, Gabriele Steidl
Institute of Mathematics
TU Berlin
Straße des 17. Juni 136 Berlin, Germany
Correspondence to: chemseddine@math.tu-berlin.de
Abstract

We deal with the task of sampling from an unnormalized Boltzmann density ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by learning a Boltzmann curve given by energies ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT starting in a simple density ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. First, we examine conditions under which Fisher-Rao flows are absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein geometry. Second, we address specific interpolations ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the learning of the related density/velocity pairs (ρt,vt)subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡(\rho_{t},v_{t})( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). It was numerically observed that the linear interpolation, which requires only a parametrization of the velocity field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, suffers from a ”teleportation-of-mass” issue. Using tools from the Wasserstein geometry, we give an analytical example, where we can precisely measure the explosion of the velocity field. Inspired by Máté and Fleuret, who parametrize both ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we propose an interpolation which parametrizes only ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fixes an appropriate vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This corresponds to the Wasserstein gradient flow of the Kullback-Leibler divergence related to Langevin dynamics. We demonstrate by numerical examples that our model provides a well-behaved flow field which successfully solves the above sampling task.

1 Introduction

In this paper, we consider the problem of sampling from a Boltzmann density ρD=e−fD/ZDsubscript𝜌𝐷superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝐷subscript𝑍𝐷\rho_{D}=e^{-f_{D}}/Z_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with unknown normalizing constant ZDsubscript𝑍𝐷Z_{D}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our approach is in the spirit of recent developments in generative modelling and aims to construct a curve ρt=e−ft/Ztsubscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡\rho_{t}=e^{-f_{t}}/Z_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT interpolating between a simple density ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the target ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If such curve admits a velocity field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and there exists a solution φ𝜑\varphiitalic_φ of

∂tφt=vt⁢(φt),φ0=Idwhere(φt)♯⁢(ρZ⁢d⁢x)=ρt⁢d⁢x,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡subscript𝜑𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝜑𝑡formulae-sequencesubscript𝜑0Idwheresubscriptsubscript𝜑𝑡♯subscript𝜌𝑍d𝑥subscript𝜌𝑡d𝑥\partial_{t}\varphi_{t}=v_{t}(\varphi_{t}),\quad\varphi_{0}=\mathrm{Id}\quad% \text{where}\quad(\varphi_{t})_{\sharp}(\rho_{Z}\mathrm{d}x)=\rho_{t}\mathrm{d% }x,∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Id where ( italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ♯ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x ) = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x , (1)

then we can use φ1subscript𝜑1\varphi_{1}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to sample from ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. An important question is, whether for a given family of functions ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such velocity fields exists. While, for a fixed time t𝑡titalic_t, the existence of such velocity fields is well established, see e.g. Laugesen et al. (2014), global existence with integrability of v:[0,1]×ℝd→ℝ:𝑣→01superscriptℝ𝑑ℝv:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_v : [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R in time and space is addressed in this paper. This is directly related to the question whether a large class of Fisher-Rao curves ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein geometry, and in particular, fulfills a continuity equation. This can be reduced to finding solutions of a certain family of PDEs. With the appropriate Hilbert spaces at hand, we show the existence of the solutions of these PDEs and the existence of an integrable velocity field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in time and space which admits moreover a minimality property of ‖vt‖L2⁢(ℝd,ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Determining φ1subscript𝜑1\varphi_{1}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT requires both finding a curve ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the associated vector field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. One way is to choose a curve interpolating between fZsubscript𝑓𝑍f_{Z}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and fDsubscript𝑓𝐷f_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT first and then to learn the velocity field. For the linear interpolation ft=(1−t)⁢fZ+t⁢fDsubscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍𝑡subscript𝑓𝐷f_{t}=(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, using above considerations, we show that there indeed exists an integrable velocity field implying the absolute continuity of the curve in the Wasserstein space. Yet, it was numerically shown that the corresponding velocity field is often badly behaved as noted in (Máté & Fleuret, 2023, Figure 4 and 6). We highlight by an analytic example the bad regularity of this flow and show in particular that its velocity field may have an exploding norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ℝd,ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Another approach, recently proposed by Máté & Fleuret (2023), considers ft=(1−t)⁢fZ+t⁢fD+t⁢(1−t)⁢ψtsubscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍𝑡subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡1𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}=(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}+t(1-t)\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with unknown ψ𝜓\psiitalic_ψ and learns (ψt,vt)subscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡(\psi_{t},v_{t})( italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) simultaneously. Henceforth, we refer to this method as the ”learned interpolation”. However, it is theoretically unclear whether the learned curve is well-behaved or the velocity field is optimal with respect to the above norm. As an alternative approach, we propose instead to deal directly with a well-behaved and mathematically accessible curve on [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ] and consider the parameterization ft=T−tT⁢fD+t⁢ψtsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑇𝑡𝑇subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}=\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Fixing the velocity field as vt≔∇(ft−fZ)≔subscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla(f_{t}-f_{Z})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∇ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) we only have to learn ψtsubscript𝜓𝑡\psi_{t}italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The resulting PDE is the well-known Fokker-Planck equation related to Langevin dynamics which has a solution with Boltzmann densities ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, if, e.g., ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Gaussian. Then, the corresponding SDE is the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process. Here, the backward ODE of (1) must be applied for sampling. Finally, we learn the networks for the above three cases and demonstrate by numerical examples the effectiveness of our approach.

Contributions.

  1. 1.

    We prove for the first time that under mild conditions every reasonable curve of Boltzmann densities is an absolutely continuous Wasserstein curve, see Theorems 1 and 2.

  2. 2.

    We verify by an analytic example that the velocity field corresponding to the linear interpolation can admit an exploding norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ℝd,ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, leading to a ”non-smooth” particle transport.

  3. 3.

    We propose to learn a curve using the parameterization ft=T−tT⁢fD+t⁢ψtsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑇𝑡𝑇subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}=\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which we call ”gradient flow interpolation” by the following reason. With an appropriate velocity field which can be computed directly from ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, this resembles the Wasserstein gradient flow of the Kullback-Leibler divergence with fixed second argument ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This curve can be also described as the Fokker-Planck equation of a Langevin SDE.

  4. 4.

    We learn the networks for the linear, learned and gradient flow interpolations and demonstrate the performance of these three methods on certain sampling problems.

Related Work.

Classical approaches for sampling from an unnormalized density are based on the Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) method, see Gilks et al. (1995), including variants as the Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMM) in Hoffman & Gelman (2014) or the Metropolis Adjusted Langevin Algorithm (MALA) in Girolami & Calderhead (2011). Arising problems with the correct distribution of mass among different modes lead to the use of importance sampling Neal (2001) and sequential Monte Carlo samplers Moral et al. (2006).
Newer approaches include the simulation of gradient flows of probability measures. In Chen et al. (2024) Gaussian mixtures are used to approximate the Fisher-Rao gradient flow of the Kullback-Leibler divergence. This corresponds to a time rescaling of the linear interpolation. In Nüsken (2024); Maurais & Marzouk (2024) they approximate the latter curve by kernelizing the associated Poisson equation and simulating a corresponding interacting particle system. Closely related Stein variational gradient descent Liu & Wang (2016) kernelizes the Wasserstein gradient flow of the reverse KL divergence. Recently in Chehab & Korba (2024) they consider a different path which they term the ”dilation path”. The associated vector field is given as the gradient of the dilation of the target density. The convolution of the density of the dilation path with (scaled) Gaussian kernels corresponds to the density of an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process.
Recently, (stochastic) normalizing flows have been widely used to sample from unnormalized densities Noé et al. (2019); Wu et al. (2020); Hagemann et al. (2022). In Midgley et al. (2023) this problem is tackled without using a curve of probability measures by augmenting normalizing flows, which are trained using an α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-divergence loss, with annealed importance sampling. In Hertrich & Gruhlke (2024) a functional F𝐹Fitalic_F with minimum ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is considered. They then learn a vector field by approximating a JKO scheme for the Wasserstein gradient flow of F𝐹Fitalic_F and combine it with an importance based rejection method. They focus on F𝐹Fitalic_F being the Kullback Leibner divergence with target distribution ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Using KL for sampling is a natural choice and it is shown in Chen et al. (2023) that it is the only f𝑓fitalic_f-divergence such that the Wasserstein gradient flow does not depend on the normalization constant of ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
Note that parametrizing the vector field using the score ∇log⁡pt∇subscript𝑝𝑡\nabla\log p_{t}∇ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is common practice for sampling via SDEs. In Zhang & Chen (2022) for example where they formulate the sampling problem in terms of a stochastic control problem and explicitly include the score into the parametrization of the vector field. The stochastic control viewpoint is also used in (Berner et al., 2024, Section 3) where the KL divergence between path measures associated to a controlled and an uncontrolled SDE is used to approximate the score. A different approach using the KL on path measures is formulated in Vargas et al. (2023). Another way of approximating a flow ending in ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is to consider the variance exploding diffusion SDE and approximating the score ∇log⁡pt∇subscript𝑝𝑡\nabla\log p_{t}∇ roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which is done in Akhound-Sadegh et al. (2024).

The authors of Máté & Fleuret (2023) present a loss based on the continuity equation and the special form e−ftZtsuperscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡\frac{e^{-f_{t}}}{Z_{t}}divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG of Boltzmann densities. This loss allows for using fixed interpolations ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and only learning vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as learning ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT simultaneously. When finishing this paper, we became aware of the recent preprint of Sun et al. (2024) comparing a variety of PDE based sampling methods. They included a similar approach as the one proposed here, using the same parametrization to simulate an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck SDE. However, coming from the Wasserstein perspective, we came to the conclusion that the associated gradient flow path is especially well-behaved. We simulate the corresponding ODE and highlight its benefits.
For the proof that many Boltzmann density curves are absolutely continuous Wasserstein curves, the main object of interest is

−∇⋅(ρt⁢∇st)=(αt−αt¯)⁢ρt,t∈[0,1]formulae-sequence⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡𝑡01\displaystyle-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t}\right)=\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\rho_{t},\quad t\in[0,1]- ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] (2)

which relates Fisher-Rao curves and Wasserstein absolutely continuous curves. This equation was studied for a fixed time t𝑡titalic_t in various contexts. In nonlinear filtering it is used to study weak solutions of nonlinear filters see e.g. (Laugesen et al., 2014, Section 2.1). Their theory for fixed time steps t𝑡titalic_t can be generalized to the case of a time dependent equation as seen in Section A.1. The close relationship between the Poincare inequality and fixed time solutions of (2) is discussed in Dhara & Kałamajska (2015).

2 Wasserstein Flows of Boltzmann Densities

2.1 General Background

Let 𝒫⁢(ℝd)𝒫superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R}^{d})caligraphic_P ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) denote the space of probability measures on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For μ∈𝒫⁢(ℝd)𝜇𝒫superscriptℝ𝑑\mu\in\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_μ ∈ caligraphic_P ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), let Lp⁢(ℝd,μ)superscript𝐿𝑝superscriptℝ𝑑𝜇L^{p}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu)italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_μ ), p∈[1,∞)𝑝1p\in[1,\infty)italic_p ∈ [ 1 , ∞ ), denotes the Banach space of (equivalence classes of) real-valued functions on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with finite norm ‖f‖Lp⁢(ℝd,μ)≔(∫ℝd|f|p⁢dμ)1/p≔subscriptnorm𝑓subscript𝐿𝑝superscriptℝ𝑑𝜇superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝑓𝑝differential-d𝜇1𝑝\|f\|_{L_{p}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu)}\coloneqq\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|f|^{p}\,% \mathrm{d}\mu\right)^{1/p}∥ italic_f ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_μ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ( ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_μ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Lp⁢(ℝd,ℝd,μ)subscript𝐿𝑝superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑𝜇L_{p}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu)italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_μ ) be the Banach space of Borel vector fields v:ℝd→ℝd:𝑣→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑v:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with finite norm For the Lebesgue measure, we skip the μ𝜇\muitalic_μ in the notation. The space 𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of probability measures having finite second moments equipped with the Wasserstein(-2) metric

where Γ⁢(μ0,μ1)Γsubscript𝜇0subscript𝜇1\Gamma(\mu_{0},\mu_{1})roman_Γ ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denotes the set of couplings or plans π∈𝒫⁢(ℝd×ℝd)𝜋𝒫superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\pi\in\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_π ∈ caligraphic_P ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) having marginals μi∈𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝜇𝑖subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\mu_{i}\in\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), i=0,1𝑖01i=0,1italic_i = 0 , 1, is a complete metric space. In complete metric spaces, we can consider absolutely continuous curves depending on the metric of the space. In the above Wasserstein space, a weakly continuous curve μ:[0,1]→𝒫2⁢(ℝd):𝜇→01subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\mu:[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_μ : [ 0 , 1 ] → caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), t↦μtmaps-to𝑡subscript𝜇𝑡t\mapsto\mu_{t}italic_t ↦ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is absolutely continuous, if there exists a Borel vector field v:[0,1]×ℝd→ℝd:𝑣→01superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑v:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v : [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with ∫01‖vt‖L2⁢(ℝd,ℝd,μt)⁢dt<∞superscriptsubscript01subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜇𝑡differential-d𝑡\int_{0}^{1}\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu_{t})}\,\mathrm{% d}t<\infty∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t < ∞ such that the continuity equation

(2005). While for fixed μtsubscript𝜇𝑡\mu_{t}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT there are many vector fields such that the continuity equation is fulfilled, there exists a unique one such that ‖vt‖L2⁢(ℝd,μt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜇𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes minimal for almost every t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. In other words, if μtsubscript𝜇𝑡\mu_{t}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT fulfills the continuity equation for some vector field, then there exists a unique vector field that solves

arg⁢minvt∈L2⁢(ℝd,ℝd,μt)⁢∫ℝd‖vt‖2⁢dμts.t.∂tμt+∇⋅(μt⁢vt)=0.subscriptargminsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜇𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜇𝑡s.t.subscript𝑡subscript𝜇𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡0\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{v_{t}\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\mathbb{R}^{d},\mu_{t}% )}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|v_{t}\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\mu_{t}\quad\text{s.t.}\quad% \partial_{t}\mu_{t}+\nabla\cdot(\mu_{t}v_{t})=0.start_OPERATOR roman_arg roman_min end_OPERATOR start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT s.t. ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∇ ⋅ ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 . Moreover, this optimal vector field is determined by the condition that vt∈Tμt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝑇subscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑v_{t}\in T_{\mu_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for almost every t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], with the regular tangent space
