see (Ambrosio et al., 2005, § 8). Finally, if μtsubscript𝜇𝑡\mu_{t}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an absolutely continuous curve with Borel vector field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that for every compact Borel set B⊂ℝd𝐵superscriptℝ𝑑B\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_B ⊂ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT it holds ∫01supB‖vt‖+Lip⁢(vt,B)⁢d⁢t<∞superscriptsubscript01subscriptsupremum𝐵normsubscript𝑣𝑡Lipsubscript𝑣𝑡𝐵d𝑡\int_{0}^{1}\sup_{B}\|v_{t}\|+\text{Lip}(v_{t},B)\,\mathrm{d}t<\infty∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_sup start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ + Lip ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B ) roman_d italic_t < ∞, then there exists a solution φ:[0,1]×ℝd→ℝd:𝜑→01superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\varphi:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_φ : [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of

∂tφ⁢(t,x)=vt⁢(φ⁢(t,x)),φ⁢(0,x)=xformulae-sequencesubscript𝑡𝜑𝑡𝑥subscript𝑣𝑡𝜑𝑡𝑥𝜑0𝑥𝑥\partial_{t}\varphi(t,x)=v_{t}(\varphi(t,x)),\quad\varphi(0,x)=x\\ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ ( italic_t , italic_x ) = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_φ ( italic_t , italic_x ) ) , italic_φ ( 0 , italic_x ) = italic_x (7)

which fulfills μt=φt,♯⁢μ0≔μ0∘φt−1subscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝜑𝑡♯subscript𝜇0≔subscript𝜇0superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑡1\mu_{t}=\varphi_{t,\sharp}\mu_{0}\coloneqq\mu_{0}\circ\varphi_{t}^{-1}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , ♯ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∘ italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, see e.g. (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Proposition 8.1.8).

2.2 Wasserstein meets Fisher-Rao Flows

In the following, we are interested in absolutely continuous probability measures with respect to the Lebesgue measure, i.e., the space 𝒫a⁢c(ℝd)≔{μ=ρdx:ρ∈L1(ℝd)\mathcal{P}^{ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\coloneqq\{\mu=\rho\,\mathrm{d}x:\rho\in L_{1}% (\mathbb{R}^{d})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≔ { italic_μ = italic_ρ roman_d italic_x : italic_ρ ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), ρ≥0𝜌0\rho\geq 0italic_ρ ≥ 0, ∫ℝdρdx=1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\rho\,\mathrm{d}x=1\}∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ roman_d italic_x = 1 } and we will address such measures just by their densities. Moreover, we will only consider Boltzmann/Gibbs densities depending on functions f:[0,1]×ℝd→ℝ:𝑓→01superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R with e−ft∈L1⁢(ℝd)superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝐿1superscriptℝ𝑑e^{-f_{t}}\in L_{1}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and f⁢(⋅,x)∈C1⁢([0,1])𝑓⋅𝑥superscript𝐶101f(\cdot,x)\in C^{1}([0,1])italic_f ( ⋅ , italic_x ) ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] ) for all x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ∂tf⁢(t,⋅)∈L2⁢(ℝd,ρt)subscript𝑡𝑓𝑡⋅subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜌𝑡\partial_{t}f(t,\cdot)\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) such that

ρt≔e−ftZt,Zt≔∫Rde−ft⁢dx.formulae-sequence≔subscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡≔subscript𝑍𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑑superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡differential-d𝑥\rho_{t}\coloneqq\frac{e^{-f_{t}}}{Z_{t}},\quad Z_{t}\coloneqq\int_{R^{d}}e^{-% f_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}x.italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ divide start_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x . (8)

In this case, straightforward computation gives

∂μt=∂tρtsubscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle\partial\mu_{t}=\partial_{t}\rho_{t}∂ italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =−(∂tft−𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft])⁢ρt,absentsubscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle=-\left(\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}% ]\right)\rho_{t},= - ( ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (9)

where it maybe useful to note that

𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft]=−∂tlog⁡Zt.subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]=-\partial_{t}\log Z_{t}.blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = - ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

This differential equation is a Fisher-Rao flow equation. More precisely, a weakly continuous curve ρ:[0,1]→𝒫a⁢c⁢(ℝd):𝜌→01superscript𝒫𝑎𝑐superscriptℝ𝑑\rho:[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}^{ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_ρ : [ 0 , 1 ] → caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), t↦ρtmaps-to𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡t\mapsto\rho_{t}italic_t ↦ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Fisher-Rao curve, if there exists a measurable map α:[0,1]×ℝd→ℝ:𝛼→01superscriptℝ𝑑ℝ\alpha:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_α : [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R such that αt:=α⁢(t,⋅)∈L2⁢(ℝd,ρt)assignsubscript𝛼𝑡𝛼𝑡⋅subscript𝐿2superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜌𝑡\alpha_{t}:=\alpha(t,\cdot)\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho_{t})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_α ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and we have in a distibutional sense

∂tρt=(αt−α¯t)⁢ρt,α¯t≔𝔼ρt⁢[αt].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡subscript¯𝛼𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡≔subscript¯𝛼𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑡\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=(\alpha_{t}-\bar{\alpha}_{t})\rho_{t},\quad\bar{\alpha}_{% t}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\alpha_{t}].∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] . (10)

Obviously, (9) delivers a Fisher-Rao curve with αt≔−∂tft≔subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡\alpha_{t}\coloneqq-\partial_{t}f_{t}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ - ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For more information on Fisher-Rao flows see, e.g., Gallouët & Monsaingeon (2017); Wang & Li (2022). We are interested in the question under which conditions a Fisher-Rao curve determined by (9) is also an absolutely continuous curve in the Wasserstein space. For later purposes, note that for Boltzmann densities (8), the second summand of the continuity equation (4) reads as

∇⋅(μt⁢vt)=∇⋅(ρt⁢vt)=(−⟨∇ft,vt⟩+∇⋅vt)⁢ρt.⋅∇subscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡⋅∇subscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡\nabla\cdot(\mu_{t}v_{t})=\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}v_{t})=\left(-\langle\nabla f_{t% },v_{t}\rangle+\nabla\cdot v_{t}\right)\rho_{t}.∇ ⋅ ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( - ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ∇ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (11)

Nevertheless, using (9), for our Fisher-Rao curves the continuity equation becomes

(∂tft−𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft])⁢ρt=∇⋅(ρt,vt),subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡\left(\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]\right)\rho_{t% }=\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t},v_{t}),( ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (12)

and in the ideal case that we can find a vector field vt=∇stsubscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡v_{t}=\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, compare (6), this can be rewritten as the family of Poisson equations

(∂tft−𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft])⁢ρt=∇⋅(ρt⁢∇st),subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡\left(\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]\right)\rho_{t% }=\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t}),( ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (13)

which needs to be solved for stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For fixed time t𝑡titalic_t, the solution of the Poisson equation has already been examined, e.g., in Laugesen et al. (2014) and for more recent work, see also Reich (2011); Taghvaei & Mehta (2023). However, the pointwise solution for each fixed t𝑡titalic_t does not ensure that (ρt,∇st)subscript𝜌𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡(\rho_{t},\nabla s_{t})( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) gives rise to an absolutely continuous Wasserstein curve, since by definition this requires additional properties of ∇xs:[0,1]×ℝd→ℝd:subscript∇𝑥𝑠→01superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla_{x}s:[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s : [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, globally in t𝑡titalic_t: i) ∇xssubscript∇𝑥𝑠\nabla_{x}s∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is Borel measurable on [0,1]×ℝd01superscriptℝ𝑑[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and ii) t↦‖∇xs⁢(t,⋅)‖L2⁢(ρt,ℝd)2∈L1⁢([0,1])maps-to𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑2subscript𝐿101t\mapsto\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t},\mathbb{R}^{d})}^{2}\in L_{1}% ([0,1])italic_t ↦ ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] ). If also, iii) ∇xs⁢(t,⋅)∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], then it is known that the velocity field ∇xssubscript∇𝑥𝑠\nabla_{x}s∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is the optimal one in the sense of (5). To our best knowledge, the following two theorems, which are detailed in Appendix A.1, tackle a rigorous solution of this problem for the first time.

Theorem 1.

Assume that 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ determined by ∫[0,1]×ℝdf⁢(t,x)⁢d𝛒=∫01∫ℝdf⁢(t,x)⁢dρt⁢dtsubscript01superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑡𝑥differential-d𝛒superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑡𝑥differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}=\int_{0}^{% 1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d bold_italic_ρ = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t satisfies a so-called partial Poincare inequality, see Definition A.7, for some K>0𝐾0K>0italic_K > 0, and that 1𝛒1𝛒\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_ρ end_ARG is locally integrable. Furthermore, suppose that αt−αt¯∈L2⁢([0,1]×ℝd,𝛒)subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿201superscriptℝ𝑑𝛒\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\in L_{2}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d},% \boldsymbol{\rho})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_ρ ). Then, there exists a unique weak solution 𝐬𝐬\boldsymbol{s}bold_italic_s in a certain Hilbert space 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the problem

∫01∫ℝd⟨∇𝒔t,∇ψt⟩⁢dρt⁢dt=∫01∫ℝdψt⁢(αt−αt¯)⁢dρt⁢dt,for all ⁢ψ∈𝒳01.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑∇subscript𝒔𝑡∇subscript𝜓𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡for all 𝜓superscriptsubscript𝒳01\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\langle\nabla\boldsymbol{s}_{t},% \nabla\psi_{t}\rangle\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb% {R}^{d}}\psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_% {t}\mathrm{d}t,\quad\text{for all }\psi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ ∇ bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∇ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t , for all italic_ψ ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (14)
Theorem 2.

Let ρ0,ρ1∈𝒫⁢(ℝd)subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1𝒫superscriptℝ𝑑\rho_{0},\rho_{1}\in\mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_P ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and assume that ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Fisher-Rao curve defined by (10), Let 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α satisfy the assumptions of Theorem 1. Then, ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve with vector field ∇x𝐬subscript∇𝑥𝐬\nabla_{x}\boldsymbol{s}∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s, where 𝐬∈𝒳01𝐬superscriptsubscript𝒳01\boldsymbol{s}\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}bold_italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the unique weak solution of (14). If ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded from above, it holds that ∇x𝐬t∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript∇𝑥subscript𝐬𝑡subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla_{x}\boldsymbol{s}_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. Furthermore, it holds that

∫01∫ℝd‖∇x𝒔t‖2⁢dρt⁢dt≤K⁢∫01∫ℝd(αt−αt¯)2⁢dρt⁢dt.superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥subscript𝒔𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡𝐾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}\boldsymbol{s}_{t}\|% ^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}% \left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d% }t.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t ≤ italic_K ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t . (15)

Note that by the Benamou-Brenier formula, see (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Equation 8.0.3), the left-hand side of (15) is an upper bound for the Wasserstein distance W22⁢(ρ0,ρ1)superscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1W_{2}^{2}(\rho_{0},\rho_{1})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), while the double-integral on the right-hand side defines the Fisher-Rao action of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

3 Neural Sampling from Boltzmann Densities

Our aim is to sample from a Boltzmann measure μD=ρD⁢d⁢xsubscript𝜇𝐷subscript𝜌𝐷d𝑥\mu_{D}=\rho_{D}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x, where we only have access to fD:ℝd→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝐷→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝf_{D}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, but not to the normalization constant ZDsubscript𝑍𝐷Z_{D}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, by following a measure flow starting in a simple to sample measure μZ=ρZ⁢d⁢xsubscript𝜇𝑍subscript𝜌𝑍d𝑥\mu_{Z}=\rho_{Z}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_x like the standard Gaussian one. We apply the continuity equation (12) of Fisher-Rao curves, which can be rewritten by (11) and division by ρt>0subscript𝜌𝑡0\rho_{t}>0italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 as

∂tft−𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft]⏟Ct=−⟨∇ft,vt⟩+∇⋅vt.subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript⏟subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝐶𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡⋅∇subscript𝑣𝑡\partial_{t}f_{t}-\underbrace{\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]}_{C_{t}% }=-\langle\nabla f_{t},v_{t}\rangle+\nabla\cdot v_{t}.∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - under⏟ start_ARG blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ + ∇ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (16)

Indeed every spatially constant function Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which fulfills the above equation must be of the form Ct=𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft]subscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡C_{t}=\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}f_{t}]italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], see Máté & Fleuret (2023). This enables us to learn Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that (16) does no longer depend on normalization constants. We will deal with the following parameterizations of ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and how to learn them:

  1. 1.

    linear interpolation: ft≔(1−t)⁢fZ+t⁢fD≔subscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍𝑡subscript𝑓𝐷f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ↪↪\hookrightarrow↪ learn vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  2. 2.

    learned interpolation by Máté and Fleuret: ft≔(1−t)⁢fZ+t⁢fD+t⁢(1−t)⁢ψt≔subscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍𝑡subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡1𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}+t(1-t)\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT  ↪↪\hookrightarrow↪ learn (ψt,vt)subscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡(\psi_{t},v_{t})( italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ),

  3. 3.

    gradient flow interpolation: ft≔T−tT⁢fD+t⁢ψt≔subscript𝑓𝑡𝑇𝑡𝑇subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}\coloneqq\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, vt≔∇(ft−fZ)≔subscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla(f_{t}-f_{Z})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∇ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )  ↪↪\hookrightarrow↪ learn ψtsubscript𝜓𝑡\psi_{t}italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

While by definition the first two settings interpolate between ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρ0=ρZsubscript𝜌0subscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{0}=\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ρ1=ρDsubscript𝜌1subscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{1}=\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we will see that the newly proposed third variant interpolates between ρDsubscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by the choice of vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., ρ0=ρDsubscript𝜌0subscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{0}=\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and limT→∞ρT=ρZsubscript→𝑇subscript𝜌𝑇subscript𝜌𝑍\lim_{T\to\infty}\rho_{T}=\rho_{Z}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In practice we reparametrize the latter curve into unit time, see Remark 3.

3.1 Linear & Learned Interpolation

Linear interpolation.

The simplest interpolation is the linear one ft≔(1−t)⁢fZ+t⁢fD≔subscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍𝑡subscript𝑓𝐷f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{Z}+tf_{D}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., ρt∝ρ01−t⁢ρ1tproportional-tosubscript𝜌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜌01𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑡\rho_{t}\propto\rho_{0}^{1-t}\rho_{1}^{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Under suitable conditions on the end points this density fulfills the assumptions of Theorem 2, see Corollary A.17 in the Appendix, and is therefore a Wasserstein curve. By (9), it also defines a Fisher-Rao curve, and the corresponding Fisher-Rao flow equation (10) is given by

∂tρtsubscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle\partial_{t}\rho_{t}∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(f0−f1−𝔼ρt⁢[f0−f1])⁢ρtabsentsubscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1subscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle=\left(f_{0}-f_{1}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[f_{0}-f_{1}]\right)\rho_% {t}= ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (17)
=−(log⁡(ρ0ρ1)−𝔼ρt⁢[log⁡(ρ0ρ1)])⁢ρt.absentsubscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle=-\Big{(}\log(\frac{\rho_{0}}{\rho_{1}})-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[% \log(\frac{\rho_{0}}{\rho_{1}})]\Big{)}\rho_{t}.= - ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ] ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (18)

Note that, ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is even a Fisher-Rao gradient flow of the negative log likelihood, see also Maurais & Marzouk (2024), given by

ℰNLL⁢(ρ):=−𝔼ρ⁢[log⁡(ρ1ρ0)].assignsubscriptℰNLL𝜌subscript𝔼𝜌delimited-[]subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌0\displaystyle\mathcal{E}_{\rm NLL}(\rho):=-\mathbb{E}_{\rho}\left[\log(\frac{% \rho_{1}}{\rho_{0}})\right].caligraphic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_NLL end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) := - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ] . (19)

There are a variety of approaches for approximating the vector field corresponding to the linear interpolation. In Maurais & Marzouk (2024); Nüsken (2024) a kernel-based method for solving (13) was proposed. In Máté & Fleuret (2023) they propose to solve (16) which in case of the linear interpolation becomes

f1−f0−Ct+⟨∇ft,vt⟩−∇⋅vt=0.subscript𝑓1subscript𝑓0subscript𝐶𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡⋅∇subscript𝑣𝑡0\displaystyle f_{1}-f_{0}-C_{t}+\langle\nabla f_{t},v_{t}\rangle-\nabla\cdot v% _{t}=0.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ - ∇ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 . (20)

This equation has many solutions vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the same ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and in order to enforce uniqueness we could demand that vt=∇stsubscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡v_{t}=\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

This approach leads to learning neural networks (vtθ1,Ctθ2)subscriptsuperscript𝑣subscript𝜃1𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝐶subscript𝜃2𝑡(v^{\theta_{1}}_{t},C^{\theta_{2}}_{t})( italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by minimizing the loss function

L⁢(θ)𝐿𝜃\displaystyle L(\theta)italic_L ( italic_θ ) ≔𝔼t∈𝒰⁢[0,1],x∈𝒰⁢[a,b]d⁢[ℰ⁢(θ,x,t)],≔absentsubscript𝔼formulae-sequence𝑡𝒰01𝑥𝒰superscript𝑎𝑏𝑑delimited-[]ℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡\displaystyle\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{t\in\mathcal{U}[0,1],x\in\mathcal{U}[a,b]^{d% }}\left[\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)\right],≔ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ caligraphic_U [ 0 , 1 ] , italic_x ∈ caligraphic_U [ italic_a , italic_b ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ) ] , (21)
ℰ⁢(θ,x,t)ℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ) ≔|f1−f0−Ctθ2+⟨∇ft,vtθ1⟩−∇⋅vtθ1|2,θ≔(θ1,θ2).formulae-sequence≔absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑓1subscript𝑓0superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝜃2∇subscript𝑓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝜃1⋅∇superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝜃12≔𝜃subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2\displaystyle\coloneqq|f_{1}-f_{0}-C_{t}^{\theta_{2}}+\langle\nabla f_{t},v_{t% }^{\theta_{1}}\rangle-\nabla\cdot v_{t}^{\theta_{1}}|^{2},\quad\theta\coloneqq% (\theta_{1},\theta_{2}).≔ | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⟩ - ∇ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_θ ≔ ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (22)

A teleportation issue with the linear interpolation. Máté & Fleuret (2023) gave examples, where for an asymmetric constellation of target and prior measure, this path transports mass into distant modes only at very late times which may cause problems while learning the corresponding vector field. Mathematically, this corresponds to the fact that the vector field vt⁢(x)subscript𝑣𝑡𝑥v_{t}(x)italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) develops a singularity in x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for late times t𝑡titalic_t, see (Máté & Fleuret, 2023, Figure 6). In this work, we demonstrate that this phenomenon is more severe: even when averaging over the space x𝑥xitalic_x, the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal field (5) explodes for late times t𝑡titalic_t. For an example in ℝ1superscriptℝ1\mathbb{R}^{1}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT involving a Laplacian ρ0∝e−|x|proportional-tosubscript𝜌0superscript𝑒𝑥\rho_{0}\propto e^{-|x|}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | italic_x | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT centered at 00 and a Laplacian-like distribution ρ1∝e−2⁢min⁡{|x|,|x−m|}proportional-tosubscript𝜌1superscript𝑒2𝑥𝑥𝑚\rho_{1}\propto e^{-2\min\{|x|,|x-m|\}}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 roman_min { | italic_x | , | italic_x - italic_m | } end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with a mode at 00 and a second mode at m>0𝑚0m>0italic_m > 0, see Figure 1, we are able to give an explicit and analytic formula for the calculation of ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the Appendix A.4. Using this formula (71), we demonstrate that ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT explodes when t𝑡titalic_t is close to 1111, and that this explosion happens more severely and at later times, the further the second mode m>0𝑚0m>0italic_m > 0 is away from 00, see Figure 2.

Learned Interpolation.

To cope with the above disadvantages of the linear interpolation, Máté & Fleuret (2023) proposed to parameterize also the flow by ft≔(1−t)⁢f0+t⁢f1+t⁢(1−t)⁢ψt≔subscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓0𝑡subscript𝑓1𝑡1𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}\coloneqq(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}+t(1-t)\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with a neural network ψtθ1superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝜃1\psi_{t}^{\theta_{1}}italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and to minimize according to (16) the above loss with

ℰ⁢(θ,x,t):=|∂tftθ1⁢(x)−Ctθ3+⟨∇ftθ1,vtθ2⟩−∇⋅vtθ2|2,θ≔(θ1,θ2,θ3).formulae-sequenceassignℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑓subscript𝜃1𝑡𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝐶subscript𝜃3𝑡∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓subscript𝜃1𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑣subscript𝜃2𝑡⋅∇subscriptsuperscript𝑣subscript𝜃2𝑡2≔𝜃subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2subscript𝜃3\displaystyle\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t):=|\partial_{t}f^{\theta_{1}}_{t}(x)-C^{% \theta_{3}}_{t}+\langle\nabla f^{\theta_{1}}_{t},v^{\theta_{2}}_{t}\rangle-% \nabla\cdot v^{\theta_{2}}_{t}|^{2},\quad\theta\coloneqq(\theta_{1},\theta_{2}% ,\theta_{3}).caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ) := | ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ - ∇ ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_θ ≔ ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (23)

Since the approximation of high dimensional integrals is difficult, for both the linear and learned interpolation Máté & Fleuret (2023) propose to use an iterative approach by solving the ODE ∂tφtθ′=vtθ′⁢(φtθ′)subscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑡superscript𝜃′subscriptsuperscript𝑣superscript𝜃′𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑡superscript𝜃′\partial_{t}\varphi_{t}^{\theta^{\prime}}=v^{\theta^{\prime}}_{t}(\varphi_{t}^% {\theta^{\prime}})∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), φ0θ′=Idsuperscriptsubscript𝜑0superscript𝜃′Id\varphi_{0}^{\theta^{\prime}}=\mathrm{Id}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Id for θ′superscript𝜃′\theta^{\prime}italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the previous minimization and to solve

L⁢(θ)≔𝔼t∈𝒰⁢[0,1],z∼ρ0⁢[ℰ⁢(θ,φtθ′⁢(z),t)].≔𝐿𝜃subscript𝔼formulae-sequence𝑡𝒰01similar-to𝑧subscript𝜌0delimited-[]ℰ𝜃superscriptsubscript𝜑𝑡superscript𝜃′𝑧𝑡\displaystyle L(\theta)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{t\in\mathcal{U}[0,1],z\sim\rho_{0}% }[\mathcal{E}(\theta,\varphi_{t}^{\theta^{\prime}}(z),t)].italic_L ( italic_θ ) ≔ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ caligraphic_U [ 0 , 1 ] , italic_z ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_z ) , italic_t ) ] . (24)

Heuristically this penalizes ℰ⁢(θ,x,t)ℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ) stronger in regions where the intermediate solution has more mass. Finally, sampling can be done in both cases – linear and learned interpolation – assuming sufficient regularity of the learned vtθisuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝜃𝑖v_{t}^{\theta_{i}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, by simulating the ODE (7). Note that in general there are infinitely many solutions of (20) and neither the parameterized curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT nor the vector field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is unique. Further vtθ2superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝜃2v_{t}^{\theta_{2}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained in this way may not be minimal in any sense. The proof of the validity of the interpolation with respect to Theorem 2 is future work.

3.2 Gradient Flow Interpolation

Recall that the linear interpolation of the energies f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT leads to a multiplicative interpolation of densities ρt⁢(x)∝ρZ⁢(x)1−t⁢ρD⁢(x)tproportional-tosubscript𝜌𝑡𝑥subscript𝜌𝑍superscript𝑥1𝑡subscript𝜌𝐷superscript𝑥𝑡\rho_{t}(x)\propto\rho_{Z}(x)^{1-t}\rho_{D}(x)^{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ∝ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that this does not take account of any local behaviour of ρZ,ρDsubscript𝜌𝑍subscript𝜌𝐷\rho_{Z},\rho_{D}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in a neighbourhood of x𝑥xitalic_x, resulting in irregular behavior of the vector field as shown in Figure 1 and 2. In contrast, widely used paths in generative modelling Song et al. (2021); Lipman et al. (2023) originate from an interpolation of densities via (spatial) convolutions ρt∼ρZ⁢(⋅at)∗ρD⁢(⋅bt)similar-tosubscript𝜌𝑡∗subscript𝜌𝑍⋅subscript𝑎𝑡subscript𝜌𝐷⋅subscript𝑏𝑡\rho_{t}\sim\rho_{Z}(\frac{\cdot}{a_{t}})\ast\rho_{D}(\frac{\cdot}{b_{t}})italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG ⋅ end_ARG start_ARG italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ∗ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG ⋅ end_ARG start_ARG italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) for time schedules at,btsubscript𝑎𝑡subscript𝑏𝑡a_{t},b_{t}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, corresponding to an interpolation Xt=at⁢Z+bt⁢X0subscript𝑋𝑡subscript𝑎𝑡𝑍subscript𝑏𝑡subscript𝑋0X_{t}=a_{t}Z+b_{t}X_{0}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z + italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of associated independent random variables Z∼ρZ,X0∼ρDformulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑍subscript𝜌𝑍similar-tosubscript𝑋0subscript𝜌𝐷Z\sim\rho_{Z},X_{0}\sim\rho_{D}italic_Z ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the spatial level. We aim to learn such a curve and an associated vector field.

In this paper, we propose to use ft≔T−tT⁢fD+t⁢ψt≔subscript𝑓𝑡𝑇𝑡𝑇subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}\coloneqq\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vt≔∇(ft−fZ)≔subscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla(f_{t}-f_{Z})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∇ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and to parameterize ψtsubscript𝜓𝑡\psi_{t}italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by a neural network. Then, equation (16) becomes

∂tft−𝔼ρt⁢[∂tft]+⟨∇ft,∇(ft−fZ)⟩−Δ⁢(ft−fZ)=0.subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡subscript𝑓𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍Δsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍0\displaystyle\partial_{t}f_{t}-\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\partial_{t}{f}_{t}]+% \langle\nabla{f}_{t},\nabla({f}_{t}-f_{Z})\rangle-\Delta({f}_{t}-f_{Z})=0.∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] + ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∇ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟩ - roman_Δ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 . (25)

Indeed, we will show in the paragraph below that this equation makes perfect sense, in particular, it has a solution for ρZ∼𝒩⁢(0,1)similar-tosubscript𝜌𝑍𝒩01\rho_{Z}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1)italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , 1 ). Then we can compute (ψtθ1,Ctθ2)superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝜃1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝜃2(\psi_{t}^{\theta_{1}},C_{t}^{\theta_{2}})( italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for ftθ1≔T−tT⁢fD+t⁢ψtθ1≔superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜃1𝑇𝑡𝑇subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝜃1f_{t}^{\theta_{1}}\coloneqq\frac{T-t}{T}f_{D}+t\psi_{t}^{\theta_{1}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≔ divide start_ARG italic_T - italic_t end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by minimizing the loss L𝐿Litalic_L in (21) with the function

ℰ⁢(θ,x,t)≔|∂tftθ1−Ctθ2+⟨∇ftθ1,∇(ftθ1−fZ)⟩−Δ⁢(ftθ1−fZ)|2,θ≔(θ1,θ2).formulae-sequence≔ℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜃1superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑡subscript𝜃2∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜃1∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝜃1subscript𝑓𝑍Δsubscriptsuperscript𝑓subscript𝜃1𝑡subscript𝑓𝑍2≔𝜃subscript𝜃1subscript𝜃2\displaystyle\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)\coloneqq|\partial_{t}f_{t}^{\theta_{1}}-C% _{t}^{\theta_{2}}+\langle\nabla f_{t}^{\theta_{1}},\nabla(f_{t}^{\theta_{1}}-f% _{Z})\rangle-\Delta(f^{\theta_{1}}_{t}-f_{Z})|^{2},\quad\theta\coloneqq(\theta% _{1},\theta_{2}).caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ) ≔ | ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ⟨ ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∇ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⟩ - roman_Δ ( italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_θ ≔ ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (26)

Finally, to sample from the target distribution, we simulate the ODE (7) backwards on [0,T]0𝑇[0,T][ 0 , italic_T ] to obtain φ~:[0,T]×ℝd→ℝd:~𝜑→0𝑇superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑑\tilde{\varphi}:[0,T]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}over~ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG : [ 0 , italic_T ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying

∂tφ~⁢(t,x)=−vt⁢(φ~⁢(t,x)),φ~⁢(T,x)=xformulae-sequencesubscript𝑡~𝜑𝑡𝑥subscript𝑣𝑡~𝜑𝑡𝑥~𝜑𝑇𝑥𝑥\partial_{t}{\tilde{\varphi}}(t,x)=-v_{t}({\tilde{\varphi}}(t,x)),\quad{\tilde% {\varphi}}(T,x)=x∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG ( italic_t , italic_x ) = - italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG ( italic_t , italic_x ) ) , over~ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG ( italic_T , italic_x ) = italic_x (27)

which fulfills μt=φ~T−t,♯⁢μZsubscript𝜇𝑡subscript~𝜑𝑇𝑡♯subscript𝜇𝑍\mu_{t}=\tilde{\varphi}_{T-t,\sharp}\mu_{Z}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T - italic_t , ♯ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Relation to Wasserstein gradient flows.

Equation (25) is well-known in connection with Wasserstein gradient flows. A Wasserstein gradient flow is an absolutely continuous curve whose vector field vt=−gradρt⁢F∈Tρt⁢(𝒫2⁢(ℝd))subscript𝑣𝑡subscriptgradsubscript𝜌𝑡𝐹subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑v_{t}=-\text{grad}_{\rho_{t}}F\in T_{\rho_{t}}(\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d}))italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) is given by the negative Wasserstein gradient (or more generally, subdifferential) of a function F:𝒫2⁢(ℝd)→ℝ:𝐹→subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\to\mathbb{R}italic_F : caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) → blackboard_R. Then, the continuity equation

∂tρt−∇⋅(ρt⁢gradρt⁢F)=0subscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡subscriptgradsubscript𝜌𝑡𝐹0\partial_{t}\rho_{t}-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}\text{grad}_{\rho_{t}}F\right)=0∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F ) = 0 (28)

produces a flow towards a minimizer of F𝐹Fitalic_F. A prominent example, see, e.g. (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Chapter 10.4), is F⁢(ρ)≔KL⁢(ρ|ρZ)≔𝐹𝜌KLconditional𝜌subscript𝜌𝑍F(\rho)\coloneqq\text{KL}(\rho|\rho_{Z})italic_F ( italic_ρ ) ≔ KL ( italic_ρ | italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) arising from the Kullback-Leibler divergence which has the unique minimizer ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since it is easy to show, see (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Lemma 10.4.1), that gradρt⁢F=∇log⁡ρtρZsubscriptgradsubscript𝜌𝑡𝐹∇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝜌𝑍\text{grad}_{\rho_{t}}F=\nabla\log\frac{\rho_{t}}{\rho_{Z}}grad start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F = ∇ roman_log divide start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , we can be rewrite (28) as

∂tρt=−∇⋅(ρt⁢(∇log⁡ρZ−∇log⁡ρt)),ρ0=ρD,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡∇subscript𝜌𝑍∇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌𝐷\displaystyle\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}(\nabla\log\rho_{Z% }-\nabla\log\rho_{t})\right),\quad\rho_{0}=\rho_{D},∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∇ roman_log italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∇ roman_log italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (29)

which is also known as the Fokker-Planck equation. Inserting ρt≔e−ft/Zt≔subscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡\rho_{t}\coloneqq e^{-f_{t}}/Z_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT results exactly in (25). The existence and uniqueness of a solution of (29) is shown in (Ambrosio & Savaré, 2007, Theorem 6.6). However, it is not clear if Boltzmann densities stay Boltzmann densities. But in the special case, when ρZsubscript𝜌𝑍\rho_{Z}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Gaussian, this is the case as we will see next.
There is a close relation between (29) and SDEs, namely the Langevin SDE

d⁢Xt=∇log⁡ρZ⁢(Xt)⁢d⁢t+2⁢d⁢Btdsubscript𝑋𝑡∇subscript𝜌𝑍subscript𝑋𝑡d𝑡2dsubscript𝐵𝑡\displaystyle\mathrm{d}X_{t}=\nabla\log\rho_{Z}(X_{t})\mathrm{d}t+\sqrt{2}% \mathrm{d}B_{t}roman_d italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∇ roman_log italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_d italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (30)

corresponds to the Fokker-Planck equation (29), see e.g., (Chewi et al., 2024, Chapter 6.2), i.e., Xt∼ρtsimilar-tosubscript𝑋𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡X_{t}\sim\rho_{t}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For ρZ∝𝒩⁢(0,Id)proportional-tosubscript𝜌𝑍𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑\rho_{Z}\propto\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d})italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), (30) becomes d⁢Xt=−Xt⁢d⁢t+2⁢d⁢Btdsubscript𝑋𝑡subscript𝑋𝑡d𝑡2dsubscript𝐵𝑡\mathrm{d}X_{t}=-X_{t}\mathrm{d}t+\sqrt{2}\mathrm{d}B_{t}roman_d italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_d italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This is an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process, which has the closed form solution

Xt=e−t⁢Z+e−t⁢X0,Z∼𝒩⁢(0,(e2⁢t−1)⁢Id),X0∼ρD,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑡superscript𝑒𝑡𝑍superscript𝑒𝑡subscript𝑋0formulae-sequencesimilar-to𝑍𝒩0superscript𝑒2𝑡1subscript𝐼𝑑similar-tosubscript𝑋0subscript𝜌𝐷X_{t}=e^{-t}Z+e^{-t}X_{0},\quad Z\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,(e^{2t}-1)I_{d}\right)% ,\quad X_{0}\sim\rho_{D},italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Z + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Z ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ) italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is independent from X0subscript𝑋0X_{0}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, see (Herrmann & Massin, 2019, Eq. (2.4)). From the closed form solution it follows that ρt∼𝒩(0,(1−e−2⁢t)Id)∗ρD(et⋅)>0\rho_{t}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,(1-e^{-2t})I_{d}\right)*\rho_{D}\left(e^{t}% \cdot\right)>0italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∗ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ ) > 0, and thus ρt∝e−ftproportional-tosubscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝑒subscript𝑓𝑡\rho_{t}\propto e^{-f_{t}}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT which implies that (25) has a solution.

Remark 3.

The dynamics of both the linear and learned interpolations are on the unit interval. To obtain dynamics on the unit interval for the gradient flow interpolation we apply an approach from the score based diffusion literature Song et al. (2021). We use a linear time schedule β⁢(t):=βmin+t⁢(βmax−βmin)assign𝛽𝑡subscript𝛽min𝑡subscript𝛽maxsubscript𝛽min\beta(t):=\beta_{\text{min}}+t\left(\beta_{\text{max}}-\beta_{\text{min}}\right)italic_β ( italic_t ) := italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t ( italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the associated SDE

d⁢Xt=−12⁢β⁢(t)⁢Xt⁢d⁢t+β⁢(t)⁢d⁢BtX0∼ρ1.formulae-sequencedsubscript𝑋𝑡12𝛽𝑡subscript𝑋𝑡d𝑡𝛽𝑡dsubscript𝐵𝑡similar-tosubscript𝑋0subscript𝜌1\displaystyle\mathrm{d}X_{t}=-\frac{1}{2}\beta(t)X_{t}\mathrm{d}t+\sqrt{\beta(% t)}\mathrm{d}B_{t}\quad X_{0}\sim\rho_{1}.roman_d italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_β ( italic_t ) italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t + square-root start_ARG italic_β ( italic_t ) end_ARG roman_d italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (31)

The SDE (31) has a closed form solution given by

Xt=1−e−g⁢(t)⁢Z+e−g⁢(t)2⁢X0,subscript𝑋𝑡1superscript𝑒𝑔𝑡𝑍superscript𝑒𝑔𝑡2subscript𝑋0X_{t}=\sqrt{1-e^{-g(t)}}Z+e^{\frac{-g(t)}{2}}X_{0},italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_g ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_Z + italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG - italic_g ( italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (32)

where g⁢(t):=∫0tβ⁢(s)⁢dsassign𝑔𝑡superscriptsubscript0𝑡𝛽𝑠differential-d𝑠g(t):=\int_{0}^{t}\beta(s)\,\mathrm{d}sitalic_g ( italic_t ) := ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β ( italic_s ) roman_d italic_s and Z∼𝒩⁢(0,Id)similar-to𝑍𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑Z\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d})italic_Z ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). As done in Song et al. (2021) we choose βmin=0.1subscript𝛽min0.1\beta_{\text{min}}=0.1italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.1 and βmax=20subscript𝛽max20\beta_{\text{max}}=20italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 20. These choices ensure that the distribution of X1subscript𝑋1X_{1}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is approximately 𝒩⁢(0,Id)𝒩0subscript𝐼𝑑\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d})caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). We then aim to learn the solution of the associated Fokker-Planck equation, this corresponds to setting vt≔β⁢(t)2⁢∇(ft−∥⋅∥22)v_{t}\coloneqq\frac{\beta(t)}{2}\nabla(f_{t}-\frac{\|\cdot\|^{2}}{2})italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ divide start_ARG italic_β ( italic_t ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∇ ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ).

4 Experiments

In this section we apply the different approaches to common sampling problems. We compare the performance of using the linear, learned or gradient flow interpolation.

For both the linear interpolation and the learned interpolation, we can choose to learn the vector field directly, or learn a potential and obtain the vector field as its gradient. In practice, we choose to parameterize it directly as in Máté & Fleuret (2023). Note that in practice for the gradient flow interpolation we apply Remark 3. Furthermore we improve performance by using learned scheduling function g⁢(t)𝑔𝑡g(t)italic_g ( italic_t ), satisfying g⁢(0)=1𝑔01g(0)=1italic_g ( 0 ) = 1 and g⁢(1)=0𝑔10g(1)=0italic_g ( 1 ) = 0, and parametrizing the corresponding ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ft:=g⁢(t)⁢fD+t⁢ψtassignsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑔𝑡subscript𝑓𝐷𝑡subscript𝜓𝑡f_{t}:=g(t)f_{D}+t\psi_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_g ( italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

A major design choice is at which points to evaluate the pointwise error ℰ⁢(θ,x,t)ℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ). The approach taken in Máté & Fleuret (2023) is to use samples along the trajectory induced by the current estimate of vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the gradient flow interpolation, we chose a different approach. We sample points uniformly from a large enough domain and interpolate them with samples from our latent distribution according to the formula given in (32), where we replace the samples from the data distribution with random uniform ones. For the linear and learned interpolation we tried similar approaches sampling the points from scaled uniform domains. However, we found in our experiments that the method employed in Máté & Fleuret (2023) led to better performance.

In the following, we evaluate the methods using the effective sample size, negative log likelihood and the energy distance Székely & Rizzo (2013). See A.5 for further details on the implementation and evaluation.

Gaussian Mixture Model.

We use the experimental setup from Midgley et al. (2023). The target distribution consists of a mixture of 40 evenly weighted Gaussians in 2 dimensions. The means are distributed uniformly over [−40,40]2superscript40402[-40,40]^{2}[ - 40 , 40 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

In Figure 3 we plot the countour lines of the target distribution as well as 1000 samples from the simulated flow and the ground truth, respectively.

For this experiment an important factor is the choice of latent distribution. We restricted ourselves to using a Gaussian latent distribution. However as outlined in Section 3.1 the linear interpolation faces difficulties when some modes are far away from the latent while others are close. In order to mitigate this problem, we experimented with using varying standard deviations σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ; the impact of this choice is visualized in A.5. We found that using a mode covering Gaussian led to the best results. In contrast, the gradient flow interpolation works well when starting in a standard Gaussian which is what we do.

Many Well Distribution.

The target is a 8888-dimensional many well distribution and we use the implementation of the target energy from Midgley et al. (2023). More precisely we consider the 4444-fold product distribution of the two dimensional density given by

log⁡p⁢(x1,x2)=−x14+6⁢x12+12⁢x1−12⁢x22+constant𝑝subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2superscriptsubscript𝑥146superscriptsubscript𝑥1212subscript𝑥112superscriptsubscript𝑥22constant\displaystyle\log p(x_{1},x_{2})=-x_{1}^{4}+6x_{1}^{2}+\frac{1}{2}x_{1}-\frac{% 1}{2}x_{2}^{2}+\text{constant}roman_log italic_p ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 6 italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + constant (33)

as target distribution. The results in Table 2 show that both the learned and gradient flow interpolations significantly outperform the linear interpolation. The learned interpolation works especially well in this setting. Here the choice of latent distribution is not as relevant as starting in a standard Gaussian is sufficient for all methods, since the modes of the many well distribution are concentrated close to zero.

5 Conclusions

Discussion.

We studied different paths in the probability space in order to sample from unnormalized densities and compared their behaviour and computibility. The linear interpolation of energies suffers from an exploding vector field, and learning the vector field and energy path simultaneously (learned interpolation) in practice solves this problem. However, there is no theoretical knowledge about the path which we want to approximate and in turn no conclusions about the regularity of the corresponding vector field can be drawn. In contrast, the proposed gradient flow approach allows for a thorough mathematical description of the velocity field and the path itself, opening the doors for a rigorous analysis via Wasserstein gradient flows and Fokker-Planck equations. We show numerical performance on sampling from Gaussian mixture models and a many well distribution. Furthermore we close a gap in the literature by showing that a large class of Fisher Rao curves and in particular curves of Boltzmann densities are in fact absolutely continuous curves in the Wasserstein geometry. Hence the existence of a corresponding vector field driving the evolution is implied, justifying sampling from the target density via solving an ODE.

Limitations and Outlook.

The methods proposed require knowledge of the domain of the target distribution. Furthermore solving PDEs in high dimensional settings remains challenging. These issues can be addressed by developing more efficient strategies to sample points at which to evaluate the loss ℰ⁢(θ,x,t)ℰ𝜃𝑥𝑡\mathcal{E}(\theta,x,t)caligraphic_E ( italic_θ , italic_x , italic_t ), such as combining uniform sampling and trajectory based sampling. From a theoretical point of view further investigation of the behaviour and regularity of the gradient flow path is needed, especially the behaviour of the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would be of interest.
