Appendix A Appendix

A.1 Wasserstein meets Fisher-Rao: Solution of a family of Poisson Equations

We will show that under mild assumptions on f𝑓fitalic_f, the Fisher-Rao curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from (9) is also a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve with a tangent vector field ∇st∇subscript𝑠𝑡\nabla s_{t}∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT222Overall, let ∇:=∇xassign∇subscript∇𝑥\nabla:=\nabla_{x}∇ := ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote differentiation in direction x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.. In order to do that, we will describe stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the unique solution of a Poisson equation in a suitable Hilbert space 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. More precisely, we show that there exists a unique s∈L2⁢([0,1]×ℝd;𝝆)𝑠subscript𝐿201superscriptℝ𝑑𝝆s\in L_{2}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d};\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_s ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ; bold_italic_ρ ) (with 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ given by Definition A.1) such that ∇st:=∇s⁢(t,⋅)assign∇subscript𝑠𝑡∇𝑠𝑡⋅\nabla s_{t}:=\nabla s(t,\cdot)∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∇ italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) fulfills the Poisson equation

∇⋅(ρt⁢∇st)=(∂tf−𝔼ρt⁢[∂tf])⁢ρt⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑡𝑓subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑡𝑓subscript𝜌𝑡\displaystyle\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t})=\Big{(}\partial_{t}f-\mathbb{E}% _{\rho_{t}}\left[\partial_{t}f\right]\Big{)}\rho_{t}∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f - blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ] ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (34)

in a distributional sense in 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For fixed time t𝑡titalic_t, this has already been done, e.g., in Laugesen et al. (2014). But note that a pointwise-in-time treatment does not allow us to conclude Wasserstein absolute continuity of our curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Therefore, we generalize their methods to a global-in-time ansatz; in particular, under suitable assumptions on f𝑓fitalic_f, we find a unique weak solution s𝑠sitalic_s of (34) such that

  1. 1.

    ∇xssubscript∇𝑥𝑠\nabla_{x}s∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is Borel measurable on [0,1]×ℝd01superscriptℝ𝑑[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  2. 2.

    t↦‖∇xs⁢(t,⋅)‖L2⁢(ρt)2∈L1⁢([0,1])maps-to𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2subscript𝐿101t\mapsto\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}\in L_{1}([0,1])italic_t ↦ ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] ),  i.e., ∫01‖∇xs⁢(t,⋅)‖L2⁢(ρt)2⁢dt<∞superscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2differential-d𝑡\int_{0}^{1}\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}\,\mathrm{d}t<\infty∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_t < ∞,

  3. 3.

    ∇xs⁢(t,⋅)∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ].

These conditions ensure that the Fisher-Rao curve (9) is absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein sense, and that the velocity field ∇xssubscript∇𝑥𝑠\nabla_{x}s∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is the optimal one fulfilling the continuity equation w.r.t. our curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as described in (5).

As a by-product, we obtain the estimate

∫01∫ℝd‖∇xs⁢(t,⋅)‖2⁢dρt⁢dt≤K⁢∫01∫ℝd(αt−αt¯)2⁢dρt⁢dt,superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡𝐾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|^{2}\,% \mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(% \alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t,∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t ≤ italic_K ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t , (35)

linking (an upper bound of) the Wasserstein-2 distance W22⁢(ρ0,ρ1)superscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1W_{2}^{2}(\rho_{0},\rho_{1})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) on the one side, and the Fisher-Rao action on the other.

Next we will define the appropriate spaces for our analysis.

A.2 Prerequisites for solving the Poisson equation

Definition A.1.

Let t↦ρtmaps-to𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡t\mapsto\rho_{t}italic_t ↦ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a weakly continuous curve [0,1]→𝒫ac⁢(ℝd)→01superscript𝒫acsuperscriptℝ𝑑[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})[ 0 , 1 ] → caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, for all Borel measurable B⊆ℝd𝐵superscriptℝ𝑑B\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_B ⊆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the map t↦ρt⁢(B)maps-to𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡𝐵t\mapsto\rho_{t}(B)italic_t ↦ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_B ) is measurable: Indeed, it is the pointwise limit of continuous, hence measurable maps t↦∫ℝdfk⁢dρtmaps-to𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓𝑘differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡t\mapsto\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f_{k}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}italic_t ↦ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with appropriate fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ defined by the disintegration ∫[0,1]×ℝdf⁢(t,x)⁢d𝛒=∫01∫ℝdf⁢(t,x)⁢dρt⁢dtsubscript01superscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑡𝑥differential-d𝛒superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑓𝑡𝑥differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}=\int_{0}^{% 1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(t,x)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d bold_italic_ρ = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t, is a probability measure on [0,1]×ℝd01superscriptℝ𝑑[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, see e.g., (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Chapter 5.3).

Definition A.2.

Let ρ⁢d⁢x∈𝒫ac⁢(ℝd)𝜌d𝑥superscript𝒫acsuperscriptℝ𝑑\rho\,\mathrm{d}x\in\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_ρ roman_d italic_x ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with density ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ. We consider the Sobolev space

H1(ρ):={f∈L2(ℝd,ρ): the weak derivative ∂xif (w.r.t. ℒ) exists and\displaystyle H^{1}(\rho):=\Big{\{}f\in L_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d},\rho):\text{ the % weak derivative }\partial_{x_{i}}f\text{ (w.r.t. $\mathcal{L}$) exists and }italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) := { italic_f ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ρ ) : the weak derivative ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f (w.r.t. caligraphic_L ) exists and (36)
∂xif∈L2(ρ),∀i∈{1,…,d}}\displaystyle\partial_{x_{i}}f\in L_{2}(\rho),~{}\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,d\}% \Big{\}}∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) , ∀ italic_i ∈ { 1 , … , italic_d } } (37)

with inner product ⟨f,g⟩H1⁢(ρ):=⟨f,g⟩L2⁢(ρ)+⟨∇f,∇g⟩L2⁢(ρ,ℝd)assignsubscript𝑓𝑔superscript𝐻1𝜌subscript𝑓𝑔subscript𝐿2𝜌subscript∇𝑓∇𝑔subscript𝐿2𝜌superscriptℝ𝑑\langle f,g\rangle_{H^{1}(\rho)}:=\langle f,g\rangle_{L_{2}(\rho)}+\langle% \nabla f,\nabla g\rangle_{L_{2}(\rho,\mathbb{R}^{d})}⟨ italic_f , italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ⟨ italic_f , italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⟨ ∇ italic_f , ∇ italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ , blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, define the space of Sobolev functions with zero mean by

H01⁢(ρ):={f∈H1⁢(ρ):∫ℝdf⁢dρ=0}.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝐻01𝜌conditional-set𝑓superscript𝐻1𝜌subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑓differential-d𝜌0\displaystyle H_{0}^{1}(\rho):=\left\{f\in H^{1}(\rho):\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f% \,\mathrm{d}\rho=0\right\}.italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) := { italic_f ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) : ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f roman_d italic_ρ = 0 } . (38)
Lemma A.3.

Assume that ρ⁢d⁢x∈𝒫ac⁢(ℝd)𝜌d𝑥superscript𝒫acsuperscriptℝ𝑑\rho\,\mathrm{d}x\in\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_ρ roman_d italic_x ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and 1ρ∈L1,loc⁢(ℝd)1𝜌subscript𝐿1locsuperscriptℝ𝑑\frac{1}{\rho}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}(\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ρ end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, (H1⁢(ρ),⟨⋅,⋅⟩H1⁢(ρ))superscript𝐻1𝜌subscript⋅⋅superscript𝐻1𝜌(H^{1}(\rho),\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{H^{1}(\rho)})( italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) , ⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Hilbert space and H01⁢(ρ)superscriptsubscript𝐻01𝜌H_{0}^{1}(\rho)italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) is a closed subspace.

Proof.

The first claim is (Kufner & Opic, 1984, Theorem 1.11). For the second claim note that for fn→f→subscript𝑓𝑛𝑓f_{n}\to fitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_f in H1⁢(ρ)superscript𝐻1𝜌H^{1}(\rho)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) with fn∈H01⁢(ρ)subscript𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐻10𝜌f_{n}\in H^{1}_{0}(\rho)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ), we have that

|∫ℝdf⁢dρ|subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑓differential-d𝜌\displaystyle\left|\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}f\,\mathrm{d}\rho\right|| ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f roman_d italic_ρ | =|⟨f,1⟩L2⁢(ρ)|≤|⟨f−fn,1⟩L2⁢(ρ)|+|⟨fn,1⟩L2⁢(ρ)|absentsubscript𝑓1subscript𝐿2𝜌subscript𝑓subscript𝑓𝑛1subscript𝐿2𝜌subscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛1subscript𝐿2𝜌\displaystyle=|\langle f,1\rangle_{L_{2}(\rho)}|\leq|\langle f-f_{n},1\rangle_% {L_{2}(\rho)}|+|\langle f_{n},1\rangle_{L_{2}(\rho)}|= | ⟨ italic_f , 1 ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ | ⟨ italic_f - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | + | ⟨ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | (39)
≤‖fn−f‖H1⁢(ρ)+0→0.absentsubscriptnormsubscript𝑓𝑛𝑓superscript𝐻1𝜌0→0\displaystyle\leq\|f_{n}-f\|_{H^{1}(\rho)}+0\to 0.≤ ∥ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 0 → 0 . (40)

∎

Definition A.4.

Consider a weakly continuous curve [0,1]→𝒫ac⁢(ℝd),t↦ρtformulae-sequence→01superscript𝒫acsuperscriptℝ𝑑maps-to𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡[0,1]\to\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}(\mathbb{R}^{d}),~{}t\mapsto\rho_{t}[ 0 , 1 ] → caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , italic_t ↦ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the associated measure 𝛒∈𝒫ac⁢([0,1]×ℝd)𝛒superscript𝒫ac01superscriptℝ𝑑\boldsymbol{\rho}\in\mathcal{P}^{\rm ac}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})bold_italic_ρ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ac end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) given by Definition A.1. Define

Hx1(𝝆)≔{f∈L2([0,1]×ℝd,𝝆): the weak derivative ∂xif exists and\displaystyle H_{x}^{1}(\boldsymbol{\rho})\coloneqq\Big{\{}f\in L_{2}([0,1]% \times\mathbb{R}^{d},\boldsymbol{\rho}):\text{ the weak derivative }\partial_{% x_{i}}f\text{ exists and }italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) ≔ { italic_f ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_ρ ) : the weak derivative ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f exists and (41)
∂xif∈L2(𝝆),∀i∈{2,…,d+1}}\displaystyle\partial_{x_{i}}f\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho}),~{}\forall i\in\{2,% \ldots,d+1\}\Big{\}}∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) , ∀ italic_i ∈ { 2 , … , italic_d + 1 } } (42)

with respect to the inner product ⟨f,g⟩Hx1⁢(𝛒):=⟨f,g⟩L2⁢(𝛒)+⟨∇xf,∇xg⟩L2⁢(𝛒)assignsubscript𝑓𝑔superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑥1𝛒subscript𝑓𝑔subscript𝐿2𝛒subscriptsubscript∇𝑥𝑓subscript∇𝑥𝑔subscript𝐿2𝛒\langle f,g\rangle_{H_{x}^{1}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}:=\langle f,g\rangle_{L_{2}(% \boldsymbol{\rho})}+\langle\nabla_{x}f,\nabla_{x}g\rangle_{L_{2}(\boldsymbol{% \rho})}⟨ italic_f , italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ⟨ italic_f , italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ⟨ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f , ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where f=f⁢(t,x)𝑓𝑓𝑡𝑥f=f(t,x)italic_f = italic_f ( italic_t , italic_x ), g=g⁢(t,x)𝑔𝑔𝑡𝑥g=g(t,x)italic_g = italic_g ( italic_t , italic_x ). Now, consider the subspace

𝒳01:={s∈Hx1⁢(𝝆):s⁢(t,⋅)∈H01⁢(ρt)⁢ for almost every⁢t∈[0,1]}.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝒳01conditional-set𝑠superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑥1𝝆𝑠𝑡⋅superscriptsubscript𝐻01subscript𝜌𝑡 for almost every𝑡01\displaystyle{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}:=\Big{\{}s\in H_{x}^{1}(\boldsymbol{\rho}):% s(t,\cdot)\in H_{0}^{1}(\rho_{t})\ \text{ for almost every}\ t\in[0,1]\Big{\}}.caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { italic_s ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) : italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for almost every italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] } . (43)

For s∈𝒳01𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒳01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we will also write stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for denoting the function s⁢(t,⋅)𝑠𝑡⋅s(t,\cdot)italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ).

Lemma A.5.

Assume that 1𝛒∈L1,loc⁢([0,1]×ℝd)1𝛒subscript𝐿1loc01superscriptℝ𝑑\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_ρ end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, the space Hx1⁢(𝛒)subscriptsuperscript𝐻1𝑥𝛒H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) is a Hilbert space, and 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a closed subspace of Hx1⁢(𝛒)superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑥1𝛒H_{x}^{1}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ).

Proof.

The Hilbert space property of Hx1⁢(𝝆)subscriptsuperscript𝐻1𝑥𝝆H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) again follows by (Kufner & Opic, 1984, Theorem 1.11) and we only prove the closedness of 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now, let (sn)⊂𝒳01subscript𝑠𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒳01(s_{n})\subset{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⊂ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a sequence with sn→s→subscript𝑠𝑛𝑠s_{n}\to sitalic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → italic_s in Hx1⁢(𝝆)subscriptsuperscript𝐻1𝑥𝝆H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ). Then,

∫01∫ℝd|sn⁢(t,⋅)−s⁢(t,⋅)|2+‖∇xsn⁢(t,⋅)−∇xs⁢(t,⋅)‖2⁢d⁢ρt⁢d⁢t→0.→superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑡⋅𝑠𝑡⋅2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥subscript𝑠𝑛𝑡⋅subscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅2dsubscript𝜌𝑡d𝑡0\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|s_{n}(t,\cdot)-s(t,\cdot)|^{2}+% \|\nabla_{x}s_{n}(t,\cdot)-\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}% \mathrm{d}t\to 0.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , ⋅ ) - italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , ⋅ ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t → 0 .

This implies pointwise convergence for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] (along a subsequence), i.e.,

∫ℝd|sn⁢(t,⋅)−s⁢(t,⋅)|2+‖∇xsn⁢(t,⋅)−∇xs⁢(t,⋅)‖2⁢d⁢ρt→0for a.e. ⁢t∈[0,1].formulae-sequence→subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑠𝑛𝑡⋅𝑠𝑡⋅2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥subscript𝑠𝑛𝑡⋅subscript∇𝑥𝑠𝑡⋅2dsubscript𝜌𝑡0for a.e. 𝑡01\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|s_{n}(t,\cdot)-s(t,\cdot)|^{2}+\|\nabla_{x}% s_{n}(t,\cdot)-\nabla_{x}s(t,\cdot)\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\to 0\quad\text{% for a.e. }t\in[0,1].∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , ⋅ ) - italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , ⋅ ) - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 0 for a.e. italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] .

Thus, we have that sn⁢(t,⋅)→s⁢(t,⋅)→subscript𝑠𝑛𝑡⋅𝑠𝑡⋅s_{n}(t,\cdot)\to s(t,\cdot)italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t , ⋅ ) → italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) converges in H1⁢(ρt)superscript𝐻1subscript𝜌𝑡H^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for almost all t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. Since H01⁢(ρt)superscriptsubscript𝐻01subscript𝜌𝑡H_{0}^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is closed, we have that the limit s⁢(t,⋅)𝑠𝑡⋅s(t,\cdot)italic_s ( italic_t , ⋅ ) is in H01⁢(ρt)superscriptsubscript𝐻01subscript𝜌𝑡H_{0}^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for a.e. t𝑡titalic_t. ∎

Definition A.6.

On 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we define an bilinear form by setting

⟨f,g⟩𝒳01=⟨∇xf,∇xg⟩L2⁢(𝝆).subscript𝑓𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒳01subscriptsubscript∇𝑥𝑓subscript∇𝑥𝑔subscript𝐿2𝝆\langle f,g\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}}=\langle\nabla_{x}f,\nabla_{x}g% \rangle_{L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}.⟨ italic_f , italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⟨ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f , ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
Definition A.7.

We say that a probability measure 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ fulfills the partial Poincare inequality (PPI) if there exists K>0𝐾0K>0italic_K > 0 such that

‖g‖L2⁢(𝝆)2≤K⁢‖∇xg‖L2⁢(𝝆)2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑔2subscript𝐿2𝝆𝐾subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑔2subscript𝐿2𝝆\displaystyle\|g\|^{2}_{L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}\leq K\|\nabla_{x}g\|^{2}_{L_% {2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}∥ italic_g ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_K ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (PPI)

for all g∈𝒳01𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒳01g\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_g ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that usually it is formulated as V⁢a⁢rμ⁢[g]≤K⁢‖∇xg‖L2⁢(μ)2𝑉𝑎subscript𝑟𝜇delimited-[]𝑔𝐾subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑔2subscript𝐿2𝜇Var_{{\mu}}[g]\leq K\|\nabla_{x}g\|^{2}_{L_{2}({\mu})}italic_V italic_a italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g ] ≤ italic_K ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but since we have 𝔼ρt⁢[gt]=0subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑡0\mathbb{E}_{{\rho_{t}}}[g_{t}]=0blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 0 for g∈𝒳01𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒳01g\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_g ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT both notions coincide.

Lemma A.8.

Assume that 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ fulfills the (PPI), and that 1𝛒∈L1,loc⁢([0,1]×ℝd)1𝛒subscript𝐿1loc01superscriptℝ𝑑\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_ρ end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then, (𝒳01,⟨⋅,⋅⟩𝒳01)superscriptsubscript𝒳01subscript⋅⋅superscriptsubscript𝒳01({\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}},\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}})( caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Hilbert space.

Proof.

We have to show that ⟨⋅,⋅⟩𝒳01subscript⋅⋅superscriptsubscript𝒳01\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}}⟨ ⋅ , ⋅ ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is positive definite and 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is complete. The first claim follows directly from the (PPI). The second follows from the fact that ∥⋅∥Hx1⁢(𝝆)≤K+1∥⋅∥𝒳01≤K+1∥⋅∥Hx1⁢(𝝆)\|\cdot\|_{H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}\leq\sqrt{K+1}\|\cdot\|_{{\mathcal{X}_% {0}^{1}}}\leq\sqrt{K+1}\|\cdot\|_{H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ square-root start_ARG italic_K + 1 end_ARG ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ square-root start_ARG italic_K + 1 end_ARG ∥ ⋅ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is closed in Hx1⁢(𝝆)subscriptsuperscript𝐻1𝑥𝝆H^{1}_{x}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ). ∎

This assumption (PPI) is usually fulfilled in our setting as we discuss in the following.

Lemma A.9.

(Bakry et al., 2008, Corollary 1.6) Let μ=e−V⁢(x)⁢d⁢x𝜇superscript𝑒𝑉𝑥d𝑥\mu=e^{-V(x)}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_μ = italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V ( italic_x ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x be a probability measure on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and assume that V∈C2⁢(ℝd)𝑉superscript𝐶2superscriptℝ𝑑V\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_V ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) such that V𝑉Vitalic_V is lower bounded. Assume furthermore that there exists η>0,R~≥0formulae-sequence𝜂0~𝑅0\eta>0,\tilde{R}\geq 0italic_η > 0 , over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG ≥ 0 such that for all ‖x‖>R~norm𝑥~𝑅\|x\|>\tilde{R}∥ italic_x ∥ > over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG we have

⟨x,∇V⁢(x)⟩≥η⁢‖x‖.𝑥∇𝑉𝑥𝜂norm𝑥\langle x,\nabla V(x)\rangle\geq\eta\|x\|.⟨ italic_x , ∇ italic_V ( italic_x ) ⟩ ≥ italic_η ∥ italic_x ∥ .

Then, there exists a constant C=C⁢(d,η,‖V‖L∞⁢(B⁢(R)),‖∇V‖L∞⁢(B⁢(R)))>0𝐶𝐶𝑑𝜂subscriptnorm𝑉superscript𝐿𝐵𝑅subscriptnorm∇𝑉superscript𝐿𝐵𝑅0C=C\big{(}d,\eta,\|V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))},\|\nabla V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}\big{% )}>0italic_C = italic_C ( italic_d , italic_η , ∥ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ ∇ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 0, where R:=max⁡{2⁢dη,R~}assign𝑅2𝑑𝜂~𝑅R:=\max\{\frac{2d}{\eta},\tilde{R}\}italic_R := roman_max { divide start_ARG 2 italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG }, such that for all ϕ∈H01⁢(μ)italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝐻10𝜇\phi\in H^{1}_{0}(\mu)italic_ϕ ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ ), it holds

∫ℝdϕ2⁢(x)⁢dμ≤C⁢∫ℝd‖∇ϕ‖2⁢dμ.subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptitalic-ϕ2𝑥differential-d𝜇𝐶subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnorm∇italic-ϕ2differential-d𝜇\displaystyle\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi^{2}(x)\,\mathrm{d}\mu\leq C\int_{% \mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla\phi\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\mu.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_d italic_μ ≤ italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_ϕ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_μ . (44)

The constant C𝐶Citalic_C can be estimated as follows: Let β:=βV,R:=2⁢‖V‖L∞⁢(B⁢(R))assign𝛽subscript𝛽𝑉𝑅assign2subscriptnorm𝑉superscript𝐿𝐵𝑅\beta:=\beta_{V,R}:=2\|V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}italic_β := italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 2 ∥ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. There exist C1,η,R,C2,η,R,C3,η,R>0subscript𝐶1𝜂𝑅subscript𝐶2𝜂𝑅subscript𝐶3𝜂𝑅0C_{1,\eta,R},C_{2,\eta,R},C_{3,\eta,R}>0italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 (not depending on V𝑉Vitalic_V) and a universal constant D>0𝐷0D>0italic_D > 0 such that

C≤4⁢dη2⁢(1+(C1,η,R+C2,η,R⁢‖∇V‖L∞⁢(B⁢(R))+C3,η,R)⁢D⁢R2⁢eβ).𝐶4𝑑superscript𝜂21subscript𝐶1𝜂𝑅subscript𝐶2𝜂𝑅subscriptnorm∇𝑉superscript𝐿𝐵𝑅subscript𝐶3𝜂𝑅𝐷superscript𝑅2superscript𝑒𝛽\displaystyle C\leq\frac{4d}{\eta^{2}}\Big{(}1+\left(C_{1,\eta,R}+C_{2,\eta,R}% \|\nabla V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}+C_{3,\eta,R}\right)D\,R^{2}e^{\beta}\Big{)}.italic_C ≤ divide start_ARG 4 italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( 1 + ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_D italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (45)
Proof.

We first show the claim for all smooth ϕ∈C∞⁢(ℝd)∩H1⁢(μ)italic-ϕsuperscript𝐶superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐻1𝜇\phi\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\cap H^{1}(\mu)italic_ϕ ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ ) with zero mean. Unfortunately in (Bakry et al., 2008, Corollary 1.6), the constants are not explicitly computed which is why we track them here. They consider for γ=η/2𝛾𝜂2\gamma=\eta/2italic_γ = italic_η / 2 the function given by W⁢(x)=Wη,R⁢(x):=eγ⁢‖x‖𝑊𝑥subscript𝑊𝜂𝑅𝑥assignsuperscript𝑒𝛾norm𝑥W(x)=W_{\eta,R}(x):=e^{\gamma\|x\|}italic_W ( italic_x ) = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ ∥ italic_x ∥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for ‖x‖>Rnorm𝑥𝑅\|x\|>R∥ italic_x ∥ > italic_R, and smooth continuation for ‖x‖≤Rnorm𝑥𝑅\|x\|\leq R∥ italic_x ∥ ≤ italic_R. They show that, if for L:=Δ−⟨∇V,∇⋅⟩L:=\Delta-\langle\nabla V,\nabla\cdot\rangleitalic_L := roman_Δ - ⟨ ∇ italic_V , ∇ ⋅ ⟩, it holds that

L⁢W≤−θ⁢W⁢(x)+b⁢χB⁢(R),𝐿𝑊𝜃𝑊𝑥𝑏subscript𝜒𝐵𝑅LW\leq-\theta W(x)+b\chi_{B(R)},italic_L italic_W ≤ - italic_θ italic_W ( italic_x ) + italic_b italic_χ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B ( italic_R ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

then, the inequality V⁢a⁢rμ⁢[ϕ]≤C⁢∫ℝd‖∇ϕ2‖⁢dμ𝑉𝑎subscript𝑟𝜇delimited-[]italic-ϕ𝐶subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑norm∇superscriptitalic-ϕ2differential-d𝜇Var_{\mu}[\phi]\leq C\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla\phi^{2}\|\,\mathrm{d}\muitalic_V italic_a italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_ϕ ] ≤ italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ roman_d italic_μ is true with constant C=1θ⁢(1+b⁢κR)𝐶1𝜃1𝑏subscript𝜅𝑅C=\frac{1}{\theta}(1+b\kappa_{R})italic_C = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG ( 1 + italic_b italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where the constant κRsubscript𝜅𝑅\kappa_{R}italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be estimated by D⁢R2⁢eβ𝐷superscript𝑅2superscript𝑒𝛽D\,R^{2}e^{\beta}italic_D italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We are left to upper bound the constants θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ and b𝑏bitalic_b. Let ‖x‖≤Rnorm𝑥𝑅\|x\|\leq R∥ italic_x ∥ ≤ italic_R. Then, we have that

|LW(x)|≤|ΔW(x)|+|⟨∇V(x),∇W(x)|≤∥ΔW∥L∞⁢(B⁢(R))+∥∇V∥L∞⁢(B⁢(R))∥∇W∥L∞⁢(B⁢(R)),|LW(x)|\leq|\Delta W(x)|+|\langle\nabla V(x),\nabla W(x)|\leq\|\Delta W\|_{L^{% \infty}(B(R))}+\|\nabla V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}\|\nabla W\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))},| italic_L italic_W ( italic_x ) | ≤ | roman_Δ italic_W ( italic_x ) | + | ⟨ ∇ italic_V ( italic_x ) , ∇ italic_W ( italic_x ) | ≤ ∥ roman_Δ italic_W ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∥ ∇ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_W ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (46)

and for ‖x‖>Rnorm𝑥𝑅\|x\|>R∥ italic_x ∥ > italic_R, by choice of R𝑅Ritalic_R,

L⁢W⁢(x)𝐿𝑊𝑥\displaystyle LW(x)italic_L italic_W ( italic_x ) =η2⁢(d−1‖x‖+η2−⟨x,∇V⟩‖x‖)⁢W⁢(x)≤η2⁢(d−1R+η2−η)⁢W⁢(x)absent𝜂2𝑑1norm𝑥𝜂2𝑥∇𝑉norm𝑥𝑊𝑥𝜂2𝑑1𝑅𝜂2𝜂𝑊𝑥\displaystyle=\frac{\eta}{2}\left(\frac{d-1}{\|x\|}+\frac{\eta}{2}-\frac{% \langle x,\nabla V\rangle}{\|x\|}\right)W(x)\leq\frac{\eta}{2}\left(\frac{d-1}% {R}+\frac{\eta}{2}-\eta\right)W(x)= divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_d - 1 end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x ∥ end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - divide start_ARG ⟨ italic_x , ∇ italic_V ⟩ end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_x ∥ end_ARG ) italic_W ( italic_x ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_d - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_R end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_η ) italic_W ( italic_x ) (47)
≤η2⁢(η⁢(d−1)2⁢d−η⁢d2⁢d)⁢W⁢(x)=−η24⁢d⁢W⁢(x),absent𝜂2𝜂𝑑12𝑑𝜂𝑑2𝑑𝑊𝑥superscript𝜂24𝑑𝑊𝑥\displaystyle\leq\frac{\eta}{2}\left(\frac{\eta(d-1)}{2d}-\frac{\eta d}{2d}% \right)W(x)=-\frac{\eta^{2}}{4d}W(x),≤ divide start_ARG italic_η end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_η ( italic_d - 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_d end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_η italic_d end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_d end_ARG ) italic_W ( italic_x ) = - divide start_ARG italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_d end_ARG italic_W ( italic_x ) , (48)

and thus the claim is true for ϕ∈C∞⁢(ℝd)∩H1⁢(μ)italic-ϕsuperscript𝐶superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐻1𝜇\phi\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\cap H^{1}(\mu)italic_ϕ ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ ) with zero mean, using the constants b=C1,η,R+C2,η,R⁢‖∇V‖L∞⁢(B⁢(R))+C3,η,R𝑏subscript𝐶1𝜂𝑅subscript𝐶2𝜂𝑅subscriptnorm∇𝑉superscript𝐿𝐵𝑅subscript𝐶3𝜂𝑅b=C_{1,\eta,R}+C_{2,\eta,R}\|\nabla V\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}+C_{3,\eta,R}italic_b = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 , italic_η , italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, C2,η,R:=‖∇Wη,R‖L∞⁢(B⁢(R))assignsubscript𝐶2𝜂𝑅subscriptnorm∇subscript𝑊𝜂𝑅superscript𝐿𝐵𝑅C_{2,\eta,R}:=\|\nabla W_{\eta,R}\|_{L^{\infty}(B(R))}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_η ,
