In order to extend this result to ϕ∈H01⁢(μ)italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝐻10𝜇\phi\in H^{1}_{0}(\mu)italic_ϕ ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_μ ), note that Cc∞⁢(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐superscriptℝ𝑑C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is dense in H1⁢(ℝd)superscript𝐻1superscriptℝ𝑑H^{1}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), see (Adams & Fournier, 2003, Cor. 3.23). Since by assumption, V𝑉Vitalic_V is lower bounded, i.e., e−Vsuperscript𝑒𝑉e^{-V}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is upper bounded, Cc∞⁢(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐superscriptℝ𝑑C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is also dense in H1⁢(μ)superscript𝐻1𝜇H^{1}(\mu)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ ) by Lebesgue’s dominated convergence theorem. Now take a sequence (ϕn)∈Cc∞⁢(ℝd)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐superscriptℝ𝑑(\phi_{n})\in C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})( italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) converging to ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ in H1⁢(μ)superscript𝐻1𝜇H^{1}(\mu)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ ). Then, also ϕn~:=ϕn−∫ℝdϕn⁢dμassign~subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛differential-d𝜇\tilde{\phi_{n}}:=\phi_{n}-\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi_{n}\,\mathrm{d}\muover~ start_ARG italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_μ converges to ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ in H1⁢(μ)superscript𝐻1𝜇H^{1}(\mu)italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ ), and ϕn~∈C∞⁢(ℝd)∩H1⁢(μ)~subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛superscript𝐶superscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝐻1𝜇\tilde{\phi_{n}}\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\cap H^{1}(\mu)over~ start_ARG italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ ) has zero mean. The first part now yields the claim. ∎

For the specific path ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by the linear potential interpolation Vt=(1−t)⁢f0+t⁢f1subscript𝑉𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓0𝑡subscript𝑓1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the disintegration measure 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ fulfills the partial Poincare inequality (PPI) given suitable assumptions on the end points f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as the next proposition shows.

Proposition A.10.

Let f0,f1∈C2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝐶2superscriptℝ𝑑f_{0},f_{1}\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be lower bounded such that there exists α,η>0𝛼𝜂0\alpha,\eta>0italic_α , italic_η > 0 and R~>0~𝑅0\tilde{R}>0over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG > 0 such that for all ‖x‖≥R~norm𝑥~𝑅\|x\|\geq\tilde{R}∥ italic_x ∥ ≥ over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG it holds the drift condition

⟨x,∇fi⁢(x)⟩≥η⁢‖x‖,i=0,1,formulae-sequence𝑥∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝜂norm𝑥𝑖01\langle x,\nabla f_{i}(x)\rangle\geq\eta\|x\|,\quad i=0,1,⟨ italic_x , ∇ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ⟩ ≥ italic_η ∥ italic_x ∥ , italic_i = 0 , 1 , (49)

and the linear growth condition

fi⁢(x)≥α⁢‖x‖,i=0,1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝛼norm𝑥𝑖01f_{i}(x)\geq\alpha\|x\|,\quad i=0,1.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ≥ italic_α ∥ italic_x ∥ , italic_i = 0 , 1 . (50)

Let Vt=(1−t)⁢f0+t⁢f1subscript𝑉𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓0𝑡subscript𝑓1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρt=Zt−1⁢e−Vtsubscript𝜌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡\rho_{t}=Z_{t}^{-1}e^{-V_{t}}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for Zt=∫ℝde−Vt⁢dxsubscript𝑍𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥Z_{t}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}e^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x, and 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ as in Definition A.1. Then, 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ satisfies the partial Poincare inequality (PPI), i.e., there exists C>0𝐶0C>0italic_C > 0 such that for all ϕ∈𝒳01italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝒳01\phi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_ϕ ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT it holds

∫[0,1]×ℝdϕ2⁢d𝝆≤C⁢∫[0,1]×ℝd‖∇xϕ‖2⁢d𝝆.subscript01superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptitalic-ϕ2differential-d𝝆𝐶subscript01superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥italic-ϕ2differential-d𝝆\displaystyle\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{% \rho}\leq C\int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}\phi\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}% \boldsymbol{\rho}.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_ρ ≤ italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_ρ . (51)
Proof.

First note that by the lower boundedness and linear growth assumption (50) on f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the normalization constant Ztsubscript𝑍𝑡Z_{t}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is well-defined, and ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is indeed a probability measure for all t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. Further note that 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ exists if ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is weakly continuous, see again Definition A.1. We now show the weak continuity of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:
Let g𝑔gitalic_g be a bounded and continuous function on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. By the linear growth (50) of f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and dominated convergence, the map t↦Zt=∫ℝde−Vt⁢dxmaps-to𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥t\mapsto Z_{t}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}e^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_t ↦ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x is continuous on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. Since it is also strictly positive on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], also its inverse t↦Zt−1maps-to𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1t\mapsto Z_{t}^{-1}italic_t ↦ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is continuous on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. By the same token, the map t↦∫ℝdg⁢e−Vt⁢dxmaps-to𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑔superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥t\mapsto\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}ge^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_t ↦ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x is continuous, and altogether, t↦ρtmaps-to𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡t\mapsto\rho_{t}italic_t ↦ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is weakly continuous.
In order to prove the inequality, we conclude by (49) that ⟨x,∇Vt⁢(x)⟩≥(1−t)⁢η⁢‖x‖+t⁢η⁢‖x‖≥η⁢‖x‖𝑥∇subscript𝑉𝑡𝑥1𝑡𝜂norm𝑥𝑡𝜂norm𝑥𝜂norm𝑥\langle x,\nabla V_{t}(x)\rangle\geq(1-t)\eta\|x\|+t\eta\|x\|\geq\eta\|x\|⟨ italic_x , ∇ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ⟩ ≥ ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_η ∥ italic_x ∥ + italic_t italic_η ∥ italic_x ∥ ≥ italic_η ∥ italic_x ∥ for all ‖x‖≥R~norm𝑥~𝑅\|x\|\geq\tilde{R}∥ italic_x ∥ ≥ over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG. Let R:=max⁡{2⁢dη,R~}assign𝑅2𝑑𝜂~𝑅R:=\max\{\frac{2d}{\eta},\tilde{R}\}italic_R := roman_max { divide start_ARG 2 italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG , over~ start_ARG italic_R end_ARG } and note that for V⁢(t,x):=Vt⁢(x)+ln⁡(Zt)assign𝑉𝑡𝑥subscript𝑉𝑡𝑥subscript𝑍𝑡V(t,x):=V_{t}(x)+\ln(Z_{t})italic_V ( italic_t , italic_x ) := italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) + roman_ln ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), it is now easy to check that V⁢(t,⋅)∈C2⁢(ℝd)𝑉𝑡⋅superscript𝐶2superscriptℝ𝑑V(t,\cdot)\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_V ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), ‖∇xV‖L∞⁢([0,1]×B⁢(R))<∞subscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥𝑉superscript𝐿01𝐵𝑅\|\nabla_{x}V\|_{L^{\infty}([0,1]\times B(R))}<\infty∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ∞ and β:=2⁢‖V‖L∞⁢([0,1]×B⁢(R))<∞assign𝛽2subscriptnorm𝑉superscript𝐿01𝐵𝑅\beta:=2\|V\|_{L^{\infty}([0,1]\times B(R))}<\inftyitalic_β := 2 ∥ italic_V ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × italic_B ( italic_R ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ∞. Then, by Proposition A.9 we know that

∫ℝdϕ⁢(t,⋅)2⁢dρt≤C⁢∫ℝd‖∇xϕ⁢(t,⋅)‖2⁢dρtsubscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑italic-ϕsuperscript𝑡⋅2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡𝐶subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥italic-ϕ𝑡⋅2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\phi(t,\cdot)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\leq C\int_{\mathbb{% R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}\phi(t,\cdot)\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ ( italic_t , ⋅ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT

for all ϕ∈𝒳01italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝒳01\phi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_ϕ ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and all t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], with a constant C𝐶Citalic_C which does not depend on t𝑡titalic_t, hence the claim. ∎

Remark A.11.

(i) Gaussian distributions given by fi:=12⁢σ2⁢‖x−m‖2assignsubscript𝑓𝑖12superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝑥𝑚2f_{i}:=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|x-m\|^{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_m ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfy the assumptions of Proposition A.10.
(ii) In Proposition A.10, the regularity assumptions on the end points, i.e., f0,f1∈C2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝐶2superscriptℝ𝑑f_{0},f_{1}\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) can be relaxed. It is enough to assume that there exist sequences of functions (f0,n),(f1,n)⊂C2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝑓0𝑛subscript𝑓1𝑛superscript𝐶2superscriptℝ𝑑(f_{0,n}),(f_{1,n})\subset C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⊂ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which converge pointwise to f0subscript𝑓0f_{0}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and f1subscript𝑓1f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, such that the assumptions of Proposition A.10 are satisfied uniformly in n𝑛nitalic_n and such that ‖∇xVn‖L∞,‖Vn‖L∞subscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥subscript𝑉𝑛superscript𝐿subscriptnormsubscript𝑉𝑛superscript𝐿\|\nabla_{x}V_{n}\|_{L^{\infty}},\|V_{n}\|_{L^{\infty}}∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are bounded in n𝑛nitalic_n.
Hereby, also the Fisher-Rao curve given by linear interpolation of f0:=‖x‖assignsubscript𝑓0norm𝑥f_{0}:=\|x\|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∥ italic_x ∥ and f1:=min⁡{‖x‖,‖x−m‖}assignsubscript𝑓1norm𝑥norm𝑥𝑚f_{1}:=\min\{\|x\|,\|x-m\|\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { ∥ italic_x ∥ , ∥ italic_x - italic_m ∥ } with m∈ℝd𝑚superscriptℝ𝑑m\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_m ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., the interpolation between two Laplacian (type) distributions, satisfies (PPI).

A.3 Existence of a solution to the Poisson Equation

Now, we consider the Poisson equation (34) in a slightly more abstract manner: Showing that a given Fisher-Rao flow ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve requires solving the following (family of) PDEs

−∇⋅(ρt⁢∇st)=(αt−αt¯)⁢ρt,t∈[0,1],formulae-sequence⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡𝑡01\displaystyle-\nabla\cdot\left(\rho_{t}\nabla s_{t}\right)=\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\rho_{t},\quad t\in[0,1],- ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] , (52)

for the vector field vt=∇stsubscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡v_{t}=\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying a suitable integrability condition. Here, α∈L2⁢(𝝆)𝛼subscript𝐿2𝝆\alpha\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_α ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ), αt≔α⁢(t,⋅)≔subscript𝛼𝑡𝛼𝑡⋅\alpha_{t}\coloneqq\alpha(t,\cdot)italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ italic_α ( italic_t , ⋅ ) and αt¯≔𝔼ρt⁢[αt]≔¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]subscript𝛼𝑡\overline{\alpha_{t}}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\alpha_{t}]over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ≔ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] are given.

In order to do that, we look to find a weak solution to (52) in the space 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Definition A.12.

An element ϕ∈𝒳01italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝒳01\phi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_ϕ ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called a weak solution to (52) if it satisfies,

∫01∫ℝd⟨∇ϕt,∇ψt⟩⁢dρt⁢dt=∫01∫ℝdψt⁢(αt−αt¯)⁢dρt⁢dt,∀ψ∈𝒳01.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑∇subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡∇subscript𝜓𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡for-all𝜓superscriptsubscript𝒳01\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\langle\nabla\phi_{t},\nabla\psi% _{t}\rangle\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}% \psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}% \mathrm{d}t,\quad\forall\psi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟨ ∇ italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∇ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t , ∀ italic_ψ ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (53)

Note that for ψ∈Cc∞⁢((0,1)×ℝd)𝜓superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐01superscriptℝ𝑑\psi\in C_{c}^{\infty}((0,1)\times\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_ψ ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( 0 , 1 ) × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) it holds for g⁢(t)≔𝔼ρt⁢[ψ⁢(t,⋅)]≔𝑔𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝜌𝑡delimited-[]𝜓𝑡⋅g(t)\coloneqq\mathbb{E}_{\rho_{t}}[\psi(t,\cdot)]italic_g ( italic_t ) ≔ blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_ψ ( italic_t , ⋅ ) ] that ψ−g∈𝒳01𝜓𝑔superscriptsubscript𝒳01\psi-g\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_ψ - italic_g ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Since ∇x(g)=0=∫01∫ℝdg⁢(t)⁢(αt−αt¯)⁢dρt⁢dtsubscript∇𝑥𝑔0superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑔𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\nabla_{x}(g)=0=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}g(t)(\alpha_{t}-\overline{% \alpha_{t}})\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_g ) = 0 = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_t ) ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t, we have that (53) is also fulfilled for all ψ∈Cc∞⁢((0,1)×ℝd)𝜓superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐01superscriptℝ𝑑\psi\in C_{c}^{\infty}((0,1)\times\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_ψ ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ( 0 , 1 ) × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

We can now prove Theorem 1 from Section 2.2, which provides a solution to the Poisson problem (52) globally in time t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ].

Theorem A.13.

Assume that 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ from Definition A.1 satisfies (PPI) for some K>0𝐾0K>0italic_K > 0, and that 1𝛒∈L1,loc⁢([0,1]×ℝd)1𝛒subscript𝐿1loc01superscriptℝ𝑑\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_ρ end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Furthermore, assume that αt−αt¯∈L2⁢(𝛒)subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿2𝛒\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ), i.e., ‖αt−αt¯‖L2⁢(𝛒)2≤C<∞superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿2𝛒2𝐶\|\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\|_{L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})}^{2}\leq C<\infty∥ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_C < ∞. Then, there exists a unique weak solution s∈𝒳01𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒳01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to (52). Moreover, s𝑠sitalic_s satisfies the following inequality

∫01∫ℝd‖∇s‖2⁢dρt⁢dt≤K⁢∫01∫ℝd(αt−αt¯)2⁢dρt⁢dt.superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnorm∇𝑠2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡𝐾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla s\|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho% _{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_s ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t ≤ italic_K ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t . (54)
Proof.

Let A:𝒳01→ℝ:𝐴→superscriptsubscript𝒳01ℝA:{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}\to\mathbb{R}italic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R be defined as

A⁢ψ:=∫01∫ℝdψt⁢(αt−αt¯)⁢dρt⁢dt.assign𝐴𝜓superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle A\psi:=\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}% -\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t.italic_A italic_ψ := ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t .

Therefore, we can rewrite our system of PDEs (52) as

⟨s,ψ⟩𝒳01=A⁢ψ,∀ψ∈𝒳01.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑠𝜓superscriptsubscript𝒳01𝐴𝜓for-all𝜓superscriptsubscript𝒳01\displaystyle\langle s,\psi\rangle_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}}=A\psi,\quad\forall% \psi\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}.⟨ italic_s , italic_ψ ⟩ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_A italic_ψ , ∀ italic_ψ ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (55)

Clearly, A𝐴Aitalic_A is a linear operator. Since 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ satisfies (PPI) the following holds:

|A⁢ψ|2superscript𝐴𝜓2\displaystyle\left|A\psi\right|^{2}| italic_A italic_ψ | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =|∫01∫ℝdψt⁢(αt−αt¯)⁢dρt⁢dt|2=|∫[0,1]×ℝdψt⁢(x)⁢(αt⁢(x)−αt¯⁢(x))⁢d𝝆⁢(t,x)|2absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜓𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡2superscriptsubscript01superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝜓𝑡𝑥subscript𝛼𝑡𝑥¯subscript𝛼𝑡𝑥differential-d𝝆𝑡𝑥2\displaystyle=\left|\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\psi_{t}\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\right|^{2}=\left|% \int_{[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}}\psi_{t}(x)\left(\alpha_{t}(x)-\overline{% \alpha_{t}}(x)\right)\,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}(t,x)\right|^{2}= | ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = | ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( italic_x ) ) roman_d bold_italic_ρ ( italic_t , italic_x ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
≤(∫(αt−αt¯)2⁢d𝝆)⋅(∫|ψt|2⁢d𝝆)≤C⁢∫01∫ℝd|ψt|2⁢dρt⁢dtabsent⋅superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡2differential-d𝝆superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑡2differential-d𝝆𝐶superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle\leq\Big{(}\int\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}% \,\mathrm{d}\boldsymbol{\rho}\Big{)}\cdot\Big{(}\int|\psi_{t}|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}% \boldsymbol{\rho}\Big{)}\leq C\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|\psi_{t}|^{2}% \,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t≤ ( ∫ ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_ρ ) ⋅ ( ∫ | italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d bold_italic_ρ ) ≤ italic_C ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t
≤C⁢K⁢∫01∫ℝd‖∇ψt‖2⁢dρt⁢dt=C⁢K⁢‖ψ‖𝒳012.absent𝐶𝐾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnorm∇subscript𝜓𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡𝐶𝐾subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝜓2superscriptsubscript𝒳01\displaystyle\leq C\,K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla\psi_{t}\|^{2}% \,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t=C\,K\|\psi\|^{2}_{{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}}.≤ italic_C italic_K ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ italic_ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t = italic_C italic_K ∥ italic_ψ ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

By Lemma A.8, the space 𝒳01superscriptsubscript𝒳01{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a Hilbert space. Applying the Riesz Representation theorem, there exists a unique element s∈𝒳01𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒳01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying (55). ∎

Remark A.14.

Note that in the case of Fisher-Rao flows, α𝛼\alphaitalic_α satisfies

∂tρt=(αt−αt¯)⁢ρt,t∈[0,1].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡𝑡01\displaystyle\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=\left(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\right% )\rho_{t},\quad t\in[0,1].∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] .

Then, the Fisher-Rao action 𝒜FR⁢(ρt)subscript𝒜FRsubscript𝜌𝑡\mathcal{A}_{\rm FR}(\rho_{t})caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_FR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is given by ∫01‖αt−αt¯‖L2⁢(ρt)2⁢dtsuperscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2differential-d𝑡\int_{0}^{1}\|\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}\,% \mathrm{d}t∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_t. Hence, the r.h.s. of (54) can be described by K⁢𝒜FR⁢(ρt)𝐾subscript𝒜FRsubscript𝜌𝑡K\,\mathcal{A}_{\rm FR}(\rho_{t})italic_K caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_FR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Lemma A.15.

Let 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ be such that ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded (from above) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. Then, for s∈𝒳01𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒳01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that ∇st∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ].

Proof.

For a.e. t𝑡titalic_t, since ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded from above by assumption, Cc∞⁢(ℝd)superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐superscriptℝ𝑑C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is dense in H1⁢(ρt)superscript𝐻1subscript𝜌𝑡H^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Now, st∈H1⁢(ρt)subscript𝑠𝑡superscript𝐻1subscript𝜌𝑡s_{t}\in H^{1}(\rho_{t})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) immediately yields the claim ∇st∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)={∇ϕ:ϕ∈Cc∞⁢(ℝd)}¯L2⁢(ρt)∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑superscript¯conditional-set∇italic-ϕitalic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝐶𝑐superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\nabla s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})=\overline{\{\nabla% \phi:\phi\in C_{c}^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^{d})\}}^{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = over¯ start_ARG { ∇ italic_ϕ : italic_ϕ ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. ∎

It follows the proof of Theorem 2 from Section 2.2, which says that certain Fisher-Rao curves are indeed also Wasserstein absolutely continuous curves.

Theorem A.16.

Let ρ0,ρ1subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1\rho_{0},\rho_{1}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be probability densities on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and assume that ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Fisher-Rao curve defined by

∂tρt=(αt−αt¯)⁢ρt,subscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡\partial_{t}\rho_{t}=(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}})\rho_{t},∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

such that 𝛒𝛒\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ and α𝛼\alphaitalic_α satisfy the assumptions of Theorem A.13.

Then, ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a Wasserstein absolutely continuous curve with vector field ∇xssubscript∇𝑥𝑠\nabla_{x}s∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s, where s∈𝒳01𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒳01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the unique weak solution of (53). If ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded for a.e. t𝑡titalic_t, we have that ∇xst∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)subscript∇𝑥subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla_{x}s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ], i.e., for every other vector field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying the continuity equation for ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have that ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)≥‖∇xst‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡subscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}\geq\|\nabla_{x}s_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ].

Furthermore, it holds that

∫01∫ℝd‖∇xst‖2⁢dρt⁢dt≤K⁢∫01∫ℝd(αt−αt¯)2⁢dρt⁢dt.superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑥subscript𝑠𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡𝐾superscriptsubscript01subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡2differential-dsubscript𝜌𝑡differential-d𝑡\displaystyle\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\|\nabla_{x}s_{t}\|^{2}\,\mathrm% {d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t\leq K\int_{0}^{1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left(\alpha_{t}-% \overline{\alpha_{t}}\right)^{2}\,\mathrm{d}\rho_{t}\mathrm{d}t.∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t ≤ italic_K ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_d italic_t . (56)

Note that by the Benamou-Brenier formula, see (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Equation 8.0.3), the left-hand side of (56) is an upper bound for the Wasserstein distance W22⁢(ρ0,ρ1)superscriptsubscript𝑊22subscript𝜌0subscript𝜌1W_{2}^{2}(\rho_{0},\rho_{1})italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), while the double-integral on the right-hand side defines the Fisher-Rao action 𝒜FRsubscript𝒜FR\mathcal{A}_{\rm FR}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_FR end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Using (αt−αt¯)⁢ρt=∂tρtsubscript𝛼𝑡¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡(\alpha_{t}-\overline{\alpha_{t}})\rho_{t}=\partial_{t}\rho_{t}( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Theorem A.13, we can conclude that ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the continuity equation

∂tρt+∇⋅(ρt⁢vt)=0subscript𝑡subscript𝜌𝑡⋅∇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡0\partial_{t}\rho_{t}+\nabla\cdot(\rho_{t}v_{t})=0∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∇ ⋅ ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0 (57)

with a Borel vector field vt≔∇st≔subscript𝑣𝑡∇subscript𝑠𝑡v_{t}\coloneqq\nabla s_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≔ ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the sense of distributions. Note that by construction, s∈𝒳01𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒳01s\in{\mathcal{X}_{0}^{1}}italic_s ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and hence, the gradient ∇xssubscript∇𝑥𝑠\nabla_{x}s∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s is already a Borel-measurable vector field on [0,1]×ℝd01superscriptℝ𝑑[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that ∇xst∈L2⁢(ρt)subscript∇𝑥subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\nabla_{x}s_{t}\in L_{2}(\rho_{t})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]. Further, (54) implies that t↦‖∇st‖L2⁢(ρt)∈L1⁢([0,T])maps-to𝑡subscriptnorm∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝐿10𝑇t\mapsto\|\nabla s_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}\in L^{1}([0,T])italic_t ↦ ∥ ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( [ 0 , italic_T ] ).

Together with the fact that ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is weakly continuous, we infer by (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Theorem 8.3.1) that ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Wasserstein absolutely continuous. By Lemma A.15, it holds that ∇st∈Tρt⁢𝒫2⁢(ℝd)∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ𝑑\nabla s_{t}\in T_{\rho_{t}}\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), if ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is bounded for a.e. t𝑡titalic_t. In this case, (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Proposition 8.4.5) immediately implies that ∇st∇subscript𝑠𝑡\nabla s_{t}∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has minimal norm ‖∇st‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnorm∇subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|\nabla s_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ ∇ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT among all Borel vector fields vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT fulfilling (57). ∎

Let us apply the above result to the curve given by linear interpolation of the energy functions f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Corollary A.17.

Let f0,f1∈C2⁢(ℝd)subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝐶2superscriptℝ𝑑f_{0},f_{1}\in C^{2}(\mathbb{R}^{d})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) be lower bounded by some γ∈ℝ𝛾ℝ\gamma\in\mathbb{R}italic_γ ∈ blackboard_R such that the conditions (49) and (50) of Propostion A.10 are satisfied for some α,η>0𝛼𝜂0\alpha,\eta>0italic_α , italic_η > 0. Further, for simplicity, assume that f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have at most polynomial growth outside a ball, i.e., there exists R>0𝑅0R>0italic_R > 0 such that

|fi⁢(x)|≤M⁢‖x‖kfor all ⁢‖x‖>R,i=0,1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑀superscriptnorm𝑥𝑘formulae-sequencefor all norm𝑥𝑅𝑖01|f_{i}(x)|\leq M\|x\|^{k}\quad\text{for all }\|x\|>R,~{}i=0,1.| italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) | ≤ italic_M ∥ italic_x ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all ∥ italic_x ∥ > italic_R , italic_i = 0 , 1 . (58)

Then, Theorem A.16 can be applied to the Fisher-Rao curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by Vt=(1−t)⁢f0+t⁢f1subscript𝑉𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓0𝑡subscript𝑓1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρt=Zt−1⁢e−Vtsubscript𝜌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡\rho_{t}=Z_{t}^{-1}e^{-V_{t}}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with Zt=∫ℝde−Vt⁢dxsubscript𝑍𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥Z_{t}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}e^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}xitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x.

Proof.

First, by the drift condition (49) and linear growth (50), the measure 𝝆𝝆\boldsymbol{\rho}bold_italic_ρ satisfies (PPI) by Proposition A.10. Furthermore, in Proposition A.10 we showed that t↦Zt−1maps-to𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1t\mapsto Z_{t}^{-1}italic_t ↦ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is continuous on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], hence (t,x)↦ρt⁢(x)=Zt−1⁢e−Vt⁢(x)maps-to𝑡𝑥subscript𝜌𝑡𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡𝑥(t,x)\mapsto\rho_{t}(x)=Z_{t}^{-1}e^{-V_{t}(x)}( italic_t , italic_x ) ↦ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is strictly positive and continuous on [0,1]×ℝd01superscriptℝ𝑑[0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d}[ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, it immediately follows that 1𝝆∈L1,loc⁢([0,1]×ℝd)1𝝆subscript𝐿1loc01superscriptℝ𝑑\frac{1}{\boldsymbol{\rho}}\in L_{1,{\rm loc}}([0,1]\times\mathbb{R}^{d})divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG bold_italic_ρ end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , roman_loc end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( [ 0 , 1 ] × blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

We are left to check the L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-condition on αt=−∂tVt=f0−f1subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝑡subscript𝑉𝑡subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1\alpha_{t}=-\partial_{t}V_{t}=f_{0}-f_{1}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. First, since t↦Zt−1maps-to𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1t\mapsto Z_{t}^{-1}italic_t ↦ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is continuous on [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], hence bounded, it follows together with (50) and (58) that

|αt¯|¯subscript𝛼𝑡\displaystyle|\overline{\alpha_{t}}|| over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG | ≤Zt−1⁢∫ℝd|f0−f1|⁢e−Vt⁢dxabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\leq Z_{t}^{-1}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}|f_{0}-f_{1}|e^{-V_{t}}\,% \mathrm{d}x≤ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x (59)
≤Zt−1⁢∫‖x‖≤R|f0−f1|⁢e−Vt⁢dx+Zt−1⁢∫‖x‖>R|f0−f1|⁢e−Vt⁢dxabsentsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1subscriptnorm𝑥𝑅subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑍𝑡1subscriptnorm𝑥𝑅subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝑒subscript𝑉𝑡differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\leq Z_{t}^{-1}\int_{\|x\|\leq R}|f_{0}-f_{1}|e^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm% {d}x~{}+Z_{t}^{-1}\int_{\|x\|>R}|f_{0}-f_{1}|e^{-V_{t}}\,\mathrm{d}x≤ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ ≤ italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x + italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ > italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x (60)
≤C1⁢∫‖x‖≤R|f0−f1|⁢e−γ⁢dx+C2⁢M⁢∫‖x‖>R‖x‖k⁢e−α⁢‖x‖⁢dxabsentsubscript𝐶1subscriptnorm𝑥𝑅subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1superscript𝑒𝛾differential-d𝑥subscript𝐶2𝑀subscriptnorm𝑥𝑅superscriptnorm𝑥𝑘superscript𝑒𝛼norm𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\leq C_{1}\int_{\|x\|\leq R}|f_{0}-f_{1}|e^{-\gamma}\,\mathrm{d}x% ~{}+C_{2}\,M\int_{\|x\|>R}\|x\|^{k}e^{-\alpha\|x\|}\,\mathrm{d}x≤ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ ≤ italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_γ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ > italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α ∥ italic_x ∥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x (61)

with a constant C>0𝐶0C>0italic_C > 0 not depending on t𝑡titalic_t. Hence, αt¯∈L2⁢(𝝆)¯subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿2𝝆\overline{\alpha_{t}}\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})over¯ start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ), and we are left to prove αt∈L2⁢(𝝆)subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿2𝝆{\alpha_{t}}\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ). But this follows by the similar arguments

≤C1⁢∫‖x‖≤R|f0−f1|2⁢e−γ⁢dx+C2⁢M2⁢∫‖x‖>R‖x‖2⁢k⁢e−α⁢‖x‖⁢dxabsentsubscript𝐶1subscriptnorm𝑥𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑓0subscript𝑓12superscript𝑒𝛾differential-d𝑥subscript𝐶2superscript𝑀2subscriptnorm𝑥𝑅superscriptnorm𝑥2𝑘superscript𝑒𝛼norm𝑥differential-d𝑥\displaystyle\leq C_{1}\int_{\|x\|\leq R}|f_{0}-f_{1}|^{2}e^{-\gamma}\,\mathrm% {d}x~{}+C_{2}\,M^{2}\int_{\|x\|>R}\|x\|^{2k}e^{-\alpha\|x\|}\,\mathrm{d}x≤ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ ≤ italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_γ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x + italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ > italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α ∥ italic_x ∥ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_x (64)
≤C<∞,absent𝐶\displaystyle\leq C<\infty,≤ italic_C < ∞ , (65)

again, with a constant C>0𝐶0C>0italic_C > 0 not depending t𝑡titalic_t. Integrating over t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] yields αt∈L2⁢(𝝆)subscript𝛼𝑡subscript𝐿2𝝆{\alpha_{t}}\in L_{2}(\boldsymbol{\rho})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_ρ ), and hence, all assumptions of Theorem A.16 are fulfilled. ∎

Remark A.18.

Hence, the Fisher-Rao curves defined by linear interpolation Vt=(1−t)⁢f0+t⁢f1subscript𝑉𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓0𝑡subscript𝑓1V_{t}=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are absolutely continuous in the Wasserstein sense, e.g., in the cases (see also Remark A.11)

  • •

    Gaussian distributions given by fi:=12⁢σ2⁢‖x−m‖2assignsubscript𝑓𝑖12superscript𝜎2superscriptnorm𝑥𝑚2f_{i}:=\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|x-m\|^{2}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_m ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

  • •

    Laplacian distributions given by fi:=1σ⁢‖x−m‖assignsubscript𝑓𝑖1𝜎norm𝑥𝑚f_{i}:=\frac{1}{\sigma}\|x-m\|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG ∥ italic_x - italic_m ∥,

  • •

    Laplacian type distributions given by fi:=min⁡{‖x‖,‖x−m‖}assignsubscript𝑓𝑖norm𝑥norm𝑥𝑚f_{i}:=\min\{\|x\|,\|x-m\|\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { ∥ italic_x ∥ , ∥ italic_x - italic_m ∥ }.

A.4 A teleportation issue with the linear interpolation

In this section we want to demonstrate that the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the (optimal) velocity field (5) belonging to the Fisher-Rao path given by linear interpolation ft:=(1−t)⁢f0+t⁢f1assignsubscript𝑓𝑡1𝑡subscript𝑓0𝑡subscript𝑓1f_{t}:=(1-t)f_{0}+tf_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ( 1 - italic_t ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, explodes for times t𝑡titalic_t close to 1111, when the measures ρ0subscript𝜌0\rho_{0}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ρ1subscript𝜌1\rho_{1}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are asymmetrical to each other.

In the following, we restrict ourselves to the one-dimensional setting ℝ1superscriptℝ1\mathbb{R}^{1}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in order to exploit the isometry from the Wasserstein space 𝒫2⁢(ℝ1)subscript𝒫2superscriptℝ1\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}^{1})caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) into the convex cone 𝒞⊂L2⁢(0,1)𝒞subscript𝐿201\mathcal{C}\subset L_{2}(0,1)caligraphic_C ⊂ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 1 ) of quantile functions, also see (Duong et al., 2024, Section 3). For the sake of self-containedness, we give a short introduction of the necessary tools: For μ∈𝒫2⁢(ℝ)𝜇subscript𝒫2ℝ\mu\in\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R})italic_μ ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R ) we define its cumulative distribution function (CDF) by

Fμ⁢(x):=μ⁢(−∞,x],x∈ℝ,formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝐹𝜇𝑥𝜇𝑥𝑥ℝF_{\mu}(x):=\mu(-\infty,x],\quad x\in\mathbb{R},italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := italic_μ ( - ∞ , italic_x ] , italic_x ∈ blackboard_R , (66)

and its left-continuous quantile function

Qμ⁢(s):=min⁡{x∈ℝ:F⁢(x)≥s},s∈(0,1).formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝑄𝜇𝑠:𝑥ℝ𝐹𝑥𝑠𝑠01Q_{\mu}(s):=\min\{x\in\mathbb{R}:F(x)\geq s\},\quad s\in(0,1).italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) := roman_min { italic_x ∈ blackboard_R : italic_F ( italic_x ) ≥ italic_s } , italic_s ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) . (67)

Then, it holds the isometric property

W22⁢(μ,ν)=∫01|Qμ⁢(s)−Qν⁢(s)|2⁢dsfor all ⁢μ,ν∈𝒫2⁢(ℝ).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑊22𝜇𝜈superscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscript𝑄𝜇𝑠subscript𝑄𝜈𝑠2differential-d𝑠for all 𝜇𝜈subscript𝒫2ℝW_{2}^{2}(\mu,\nu)=\int_{0}^{1}|Q_{\mu}(s)-Q_{\nu}(s)|^{2}\,\mathrm{d}s\quad% \text{for all }\mu,\nu\in\mathcal{P}_{2}(\mathbb{R}).italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ , italic_ν ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ν end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_s for all italic_μ , italic_ν ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( blackboard_R ) . (68)

Now, by (Ambrosio et al., 2005, Theorem 8.3.1), the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal field vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT belonging to an absolutely continuous Wasserstein curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be characterized by the metric derivative of the curve via

‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)=|ρ′⁢(t)|:=lims→tW2⁢(ρt,ρs)|t−s|for a.e. ⁢t∈[0,1].formulae-sequencesubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝜌′𝑡assignsubscript→𝑠𝑡subscript𝑊2subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝜌𝑠𝑡𝑠for a.e. 𝑡01\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}=|\rho^{\prime}(t)|:=\lim_{s\to t}\frac{W_{2}(\rho_% {t},\rho_{s})}{|t-s|}\quad\text{for a.e. }t\in[0,1].∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = | italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) | := roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s → italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_t - italic_s | end_ARG for a.e. italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] . (69)

Using the aforementioned isometry (68) and Komura’s theorem, it holds for a.e. t∈[0,1]𝑡01t\in[0,1]italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ]

lims→tW2⁢(ρt,ρs)|t−s|=lims→t‖Qρt−Qρs‖L2⁢(0,1)|t−s|=‖∂t(Qρt)‖L2⁢(0,1).subscript→𝑠𝑡subscript𝑊2subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝜌𝑠𝑡𝑠subscript→𝑠𝑡subscriptnormsubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑠subscript𝐿201𝑡𝑠subscriptnormsubscript𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝐿201\lim_{s\to t}\frac{W_{2}(\rho_{t},\rho_{s})}{|t-s|}=\lim_{s\to t}\frac{\|Q_{% \rho_{t}}-Q_{\rho_{s}}\|_{L_{2}(0,1)}}{|t-s|}=\|\partial_{t}(Q_{\rho_{t}})\|_{% L_{2}(0,1)}.roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s → italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG | italic_t - italic_s | end_ARG = roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s → italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG ∥ italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG | italic_t - italic_s | end_ARG = ∥ ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 1 ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (70)

Hence, if we can explicitly compute the quantiles Qρtsubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡Q_{\rho_{t}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (and its time derivative), we get an analytic representation of ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)subscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT via

‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)2=∫01(∂t(Qρt)⁢(s))2⁢ds.superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2superscriptsubscript01superscriptsubscript𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡𝑠2differential-d𝑠\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}=\int_{0}^{1}\Big{(}\partial_{t}(Q_{\rho_{t}})(% s)\Big{)}^{2}\,\mathrm{d}s.∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_s ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_d italic_s . (71)

In order to do so, we choose the prior and target measures the following way: Let f0⁢(x):=|x|assignsubscript𝑓0𝑥𝑥f_{0}(x):=|x|italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := | italic_x | and f1⁢(x):=2⁢min⁡{|x|,|x−m|}assignsubscript𝑓1𝑥2𝑥𝑥𝑚f_{1}(x):=2\min\{|x|,|x-m|\}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := 2 roman_min { | italic_x | , | italic_x - italic_m | }, where the second mode m>0𝑚0m>0italic_m > 0 is fixed for the moment. By Corollary A.17 and Remark A.18, the Fisher-Rao curve ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT given by linear interpolation of f0,f1subscript𝑓0subscript𝑓1f_{0},f_{1}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is Wasserstein absolutely continuous. Now, it is straightforward (but tedious) to explicitly calculate the CDF and quantile function of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT:

First, since ρt∝ρ01−t⁢ρ1tproportional-tosubscript𝜌𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜌01𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜌1𝑡\rho_{t}\propto\rho_{0}^{1-t}\rho_{1}^{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 2⁢min⁡{|x|,|x−m|}=|x|+|x−m|−||x|−|x−m||2𝑥𝑥𝑚𝑥𝑥𝑚𝑥𝑥𝑚2\min\{|x|,|x-m|\}=|x|+|x-m|-\big{|}|x|-|x-m|\big{|}2 roman_min { | italic_x | , | italic_x - italic_m | } = | italic_x | + | italic_x - italic_m | - | | italic_x | - | italic_x - italic_m | |, we obtain

ρt∝e−|x⁢|−t|⁢x−m⁢|+t|⁢|x|−|x−m||for all ⁢x∈ℝ,t∈[0,1],formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscript𝜌𝑡superscript𝑒𝑥𝑡𝑥𝑚𝑡𝑥𝑥𝑚formulae-sequencefor all 𝑥ℝ𝑡01\rho_{t}\propto e^{-|x|-t|x-m|+t||x|-|x-m||}\quad\text{for all }x\in\mathbb{R}% ,~{}t\in[0,1],italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∝ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - | italic_x | - italic_t | italic_x - italic_m | + italic_t | | italic_x | - | italic_x - italic_m | | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all italic_x ∈ blackboard_R , italic_t ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] , (72)

up to a normalization constant Ztsubscript𝑍𝑡Z_{t}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which we calculate below.

Calculating the CDF of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

By dissolving the absolute values on suitable subintervals, we obtain for the CDF

where the normalization constant is hence given by

Zt=Zt⋅Fρt⁢(∞)=subscript𝑍𝑡⋅subscript𝑍𝑡subscript𝐹subscript𝜌𝑡absent\displaystyle Z_{t}=Z_{t}\cdot F_{\rho_{t}}(\infty)~{}=~{}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ∞ ) = 21+t−(11+t+1−1+3⁢t)⁢e−m2⁢(1+t)21𝑡11𝑡113𝑡superscript𝑒𝑚21𝑡\displaystyle\frac{2}{1+t}-\Big{(}\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}\Big{)}e^{-% \frac{m}{2}(1+t)}divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (78)
+\displaystyle++ (11+t+1−1+3⁢t)⁢e−m⁢(1−t).11𝑡113𝑡superscript𝑒𝑚1𝑡\displaystyle\Big{(}\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}\Big{)}e^{-m(1-t)}.( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m ( 1 - italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Calculating the quantile function of ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Since Fρt⁢(⋅)subscript𝐹subscript𝜌𝑡⋅F_{\rho_{t}}(\cdot)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( ⋅ ) is continuous and strictly increasing, its inverse is given by Fρt−1=Qρtsuperscriptsubscript𝐹subscript𝜌𝑡1subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡F_{\rho_{t}}^{-1}=Q_{\rho_{t}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A simple calculation now yields

Qρt⁢(s)=11+t⁢ln⁡(Zt⁢(1+t)⁢s),0<s≤s1,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡𝑠11𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡1𝑡𝑠0𝑠subscript𝑠1Q_{\rho_{t}}(s)~{}=~{}\frac{1}{1+t}\ln\big{(}Z_{t}(1+t)s\big{)},\quad 0<s\leq s% _{1},italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG roman_ln ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_t ) italic_s ) , 0 < italic_s ≤ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (80)
Qρt⁢(s)=−11+t⁢ln⁡(−Zt⁢(1+t)⁢s+2),s1≤s≤s2,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡𝑠11𝑡subscript𝑍𝑡1𝑡𝑠2subscript𝑠1𝑠subscript𝑠2Q_{\rho_{t}}(s)~{}=~{}-\frac{1}{1+t}\ln\big{(}-Z_{t}(1+t)s+2\big{)},\quad s_{1% }\leq s\leq s_{2},italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG roman_ln ( - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_t ) italic_s + 2 ) , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (81)
Qρt⁢(s)=ln⁡((−1+3⁢t)⁢(s⁢Zt−21+t+(11+t+1−1+3⁢t)⁢e−m2⁢(1+t)))+2⁢t⁢m−1+3⁢t,s2≤s≤s3,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡𝑠13𝑡𝑠subscript𝑍𝑡21𝑡11𝑡113𝑡superscript𝑒𝑚21𝑡2𝑡𝑚13𝑡subscript𝑠2𝑠subscript𝑠3Q_{\rho_{t}}(s)~{}=~{}\frac{\ln\big{(}(-1+3t)(sZ_{t}-\frac{2}{1+t}+(\frac{1}{1% +t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t})e^{-\frac{m}{2}(1+t)})\big{)}+2tm}{-1+3t},\quad s_{2}\leq s% \leq s_{3},italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG roman_ln ( ( - 1 + 3 italic_t ) ( italic_s italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) + 2 italic_t italic_m end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_s ≤ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (82)
Qρt⁢(s)=−ln⁡(Zt⁢(1+t)⁢(1−s))+2⁢t⁢m1+t,s3≤s<1.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡𝑠subscript𝑍𝑡1𝑡1𝑠2𝑡𝑚1𝑡subscript𝑠3𝑠1Q_{\rho_{t}}(s)~{}=~{}\frac{-\ln\big{(}Z_{t}(1+t)(1-s)\big{)}+2tm}{1+t},\quad s% _{3}\leq s<1.italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG - roman_ln ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_t ) ( 1 - italic_s ) ) + 2 italic_t italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_s < 1 . (83)

Here, the subintervals are given by

s1=1Zt⁢(1+t),subscript𝑠11subscript𝑍𝑡1𝑡s_{1}=\frac{1}{Z_{t}(1+t)},italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_t ) end_ARG , (84)
s2=1Zt⁢(21+t−11+t⁢e−m2⁢(1+t)),subscript𝑠21subscript𝑍𝑡21𝑡11𝑡superscript𝑒𝑚21𝑡s_{2}=\frac{1}{Z_{t}}\big{(}\frac{2}{1+t}-\frac{1}{1+t}e^{-\frac{m}{2}(1+t)}% \big{)},italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (85)
s3=1Zt⁢(21+t−(11+t+1−1+3⁢t)⁢e−m2⁢(1+t)+1−1+3⁢t⁢e−m⁢(1−t)).subscript𝑠31subscript𝑍𝑡21𝑡11𝑡113𝑡superscript𝑒𝑚21𝑡113𝑡superscript𝑒𝑚1𝑡s_{3}=\frac{1}{Z_{t}}\big{(}\frac{2}{1+t}-(\frac{1}{1+t}+\frac{1}{-1+3t})e^{-% \frac{m}{2}(1+t)}+\frac{1}{-1+3t}e^{-m(1-t)}\big{)}.italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_t end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG - 1 + 3 italic_t end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_m ( 1 - italic_t ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (86)

Calculating the time derivative ∂tQρtsubscript𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡\partial_{t}Q_{\rho_{t}}∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Using standard differentiation rules, the time derivative of Qρtsubscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡Q_{\rho_{t}}italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be computed separately on each subinterval (si,si+1)subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑠𝑖1(s_{i},s_{i+1})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Since the resulting derivatives become unbearably long, we only include them in the Supplementary Material. Nevertheless, they can be computed analytically as elementary functions, and be inserted into the desired integral (71). By numerical integration, we can finally approximate the norm ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT arbitrarily close. The computed results are depicted in Figure 2 for different values of the mode m>0𝑚0m>0italic_m > 0; roughly speaking, for late times t∼1similar-to𝑡1t\sim 1italic_t ∼ 1, the norm of the velocity field grows exponentially with m𝑚mitalic_m.

On a side note, the integration of ∂tQρtsubscript𝑡subscript𝑄subscript𝜌𝑡\partial_{t}Q_{\rho_{t}}∂ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only on the subintervals (s1,s2)subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2(s_{1},s_{2})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and (s2,s3)subscript𝑠2subscript𝑠3(s_{2},s_{3})( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) contributes to the explosion of ‖vt‖L2⁢(ρt)2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡2\|v_{t}\|_{L_{2}(\rho_{t})}^{2}∥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Intuitively, this corresponds to the fact that mass gets shifted very abruptly mainly in the areas x∈(0,m2)𝑥0𝑚2x\in(0,\frac{m}{2})italic_x ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) and (m2,m)𝑚2𝑚(\frac{m}{2},m)( divide start_ARG italic_m end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , italic_m ) for late times t𝑡titalic_t.

A.5 Additional Details on the Experiments

Implementation and evaluation details.

We implement the algorithms in Pytorch Paszke et al. (2019). For both experiments we use standard MLPs with ”swish” activation functions. For the linear and learned interpolations we parameterize the vector fields directly. The learned interpolation also uses the same network for ψ𝜓\psiitalic_ψ. The linear interpolation uses the same network for the time dependent function Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the learned and gradient flow interpolations we implement Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the same network with less parameters. The gradient flow interpolation also uses a smaller network for the time scheduling function g𝑔gitalic_g as defined in Section 4. In case of normalized energy functions we can omit the parametrization of Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for the learned and gradient flow interpolations. We simulate the corresponding ODEs using the torchdiffeq Chen (2018) package with the Runge-Kutta adaptive step size solver (”dopri5”). For the linear and learned interpolation we use 50505050 time steps along which the loss is computed and the gradients are accumulated with a batch size of 256256256256. For the gradient flow interpolation we sample 4096409640964096 particles at random uniform time points and therefore do not accumulate gradients. For the GMM example we train the linear and learned interpolations for 5∗1045superscript1045*10^{4}5 ∗ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations. For the many well example we train the linear interpolation for 5∗1045superscript1045*10^{4}5 ∗ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the learned for 4∗1044superscript1044*10^{4}4 ∗ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations. The gradient flow interpolation is trained for 4∗1054superscript1054*10^{5}4 ∗ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iterations in both experiments.
We compute log weights of the generated samples by using the continuous change of variables formula and the corresponding implementation from Chen (2018). We evaluate the methods by generating 5∗1045superscript1045*10^{4}5 ∗ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples and log weight and computing the effective sample size, negative log likelihood and energy distance. We report mean and standard deviation over 10101010 evaluation runs. The effective sample size is computed as in Midgley et al. (2023). We compute the energy distance using the GeomLoss library Feydy et al. (2019). For the target energy functions and plotting utilities we use the code provided in Midgley et al. (2023).

The gradient flow interpolation faced some difficulty in the many well experiment when, while sampling, particles entered regions of very low density. This could severely affect sampling times when using the adaptive step size solver. Therefore we used an Euler scheme and resampled a given batch if a NaN error is raised. This happens approximately for 0.01%percent0.010.01\%0.01 % of the particles.

Choice of latent distribution.

The linear and learned interpolations depend significantly on the choice of initial distribution. In the following we visualize and compare numerically the results when starting in Gaussians with different standard deviations. Note that when using a small standard deviation not all modes are recovered. On the other hand choosing a very large standard deviation leads to the modes close to 00 not receiving enough mass.
